{{refimprove|date=March 2014}} {{About|the Italian clothier|the surname|Canali (surname)|the village in Azerbaijan|Canalı}} {{Infobox company | name = Canali | logo = Canali logo.jpg | caption = | trading_name = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | romanized = | former type = | type = | traded_as = | industry = [[Tailors]] | genre = | fate = | predecessor = | successor = | foundation = Italy 1934 | founder = The Canali family | defunct = | location_city = | location_country = Sovico, Italy{{cite web | url=http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=5632672 | title=Company Overview of CANALI s.p.a. | publisher=Bloomberg BusinessWeek | accessdate=13 March 2014}} | locations = | area_served = | key_people = Paolo Canali (Sales & Marketing Director){{cite web | url=http://it.linkedin.com/pub/paolo-canali/8/168/2b7 | title=Paolo Canali profile | publisher=[[LinkedIn]] | accessdate=16 June 2014 | archive-url=https://archive.is/20140629210634/http://it.linkedin.com/pub/paolo-canali/8/168/2b7# | archive-date=29 June 2014 | dead-url=yes | df=dmy-all }} {{cite web | url=http://www.mffashion.com/en/coverstory/2014/05/28/canali-relaunches-at-80-years | title=Canali relaunches at 80 years | publisher=MFfashion | accessdate=16 June 2014}}
Andrea Pompilio (Creative Consultant){{cite web | url=http://www.wwd.com/fashion-news/fashion-scoops/canali-names-pompilio-7587820?src=nl/mornReport/20140313 | title=Canali Taps Andrea Pompilio as Creative Consultant | publisher=WWD | date=13 March 2014 | accessdate=13 March 2014 | author=Zargani, Luisa}}
Elisabetta Canali (Global Communication Director){{cite web | url=http://www.wwd.com/media-news/fashion-memopad/canali-launching-revamped-web-site-with-short-film-7345779?src=search_links | title=Canali Launching Revamped Web Site With Short Film | publisher=WWD | date=10 January 2014 | accessdate=13 March 2014 | author=Zargani, Luisa}} | products = Luxury Men's Clothing | production = | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = 1,700 | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | homepage = {{URL|www.canali.com}} | footnotes = | intl = | bodystyle = }} '''Canali''' is an [[Culture of Italy|Italian]] [[luxury goods|luxury]] [[menswear]] brand.{{cite web | url=http://business.highbeam.com/company-profiles/info/774935/canali-s-p-a | title=Canali S.p.A. | publisher=HighBeam Company profiles | accessdate=13 March 2014}} It is available at its stores and luxury department stores worldwide. ==History== [[File:HK Central IFC mall Canali shop.jpg|thumb|A shop of Canali at [[IFC Mall (Hong Kong)|IFC Mall]], Hong Kong]] Canali was founded in 1934 by Giacomo Canali and Giovanni Canali as a [[family business]].{{cite web | url=http://fashionbi.com/brands/canali | title=Canali Financial Report | publisher=Fashion Bi | accessdate=13 March 2014}}{{cite web | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/luxury/mens-style/7766/road-map-to-success-italian-style.html | title=Road map to success, Italian style | publisher=The Telegraph | date=23 October 2013 | accessdate=13 March 2014 | author=Leitch, Luke}}Canali.com [http://www.canali.com/en/heritage Heritage] In the 1950s, the ownership of Canali passed on to the second generation of the family. In the 1970s, Canali was the first Italian tailor to introduce mechanised cutting machines. Canali opened its first flagship boutique in [[Milan]].{{citation needed|date=March 2014}} In 2010, [[New York Yankees]] pitcher [[Mariano Rivera]] was the spokesmodel for a Canali advertisement campaign.{{cite web | url=http://www.wwd.com/menswear-news/retail-business/canali-to-use-rivera-in-fall-ads-3220077?src=search_links | title=Canali to Use Mariano Rivera in Fall Ads | publisher=WWD | date=16 August 2010 | accessdate=13 March 2014}} {{As of |June 2013}}, led by the third generation of the family, Canali employs 1,700 people in seven factories in Italy, where it makes about 250,000 individual pieces of clothing annually.{{cite web | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/luxury/mens-style/6974/canali-is-a-superpower-of-suiting-and-semi-formal-menswear-worn-by-barack-obama.html | title=Mencyclopaedia: Canali | publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]] | date=21 June 2013 | accessdate=13 March 2014 | author=Leitch, Luke}} In 2012, 87.5% of the total production was exported; on average 1,400 [[men's suit]]s and 1,600 pairs of [[trousers]] were manufactured daily.{{citation needed|date=March 2014}}. Canali has [[retail]] locations in Europe, North America, South America, East Asia, Central Asia, Africa and Australia.[http://www.canali.com/intl/store-finder Store finder] canali.com == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.canali.com Official website] {{use dmy dates|date=February 2011}} ==See also== *[[Brioni (fashion)|Brioni]] *[[Kiton]] *[[Armani]] *[[Corneliani]] *[[Bottega Veneta]] *[[Brunello Cucinelli (company)]] *[[Made in Italy]] *[[Ermenegildo Zegna]] {{Italy topics}} [[Category:Clothing companies of Italy]] [[Category:Italian suit makers]] [[Category:Luxury brands]]

{{multiple image| align = right | direction = horizontal | header = | header_align = left/right/center | footer = '''Left image''': Chinese-made [[sancai]] shard, 9–10th century, found in [[Samarra]]. [[British Museum]].
'''Right image''': Iraqi earthen jar, 9th century, derived from [[Tang Dynasty|Tang]] export wares. [[British Museum]].| footer_align = left | image1 =Chinese sancai sherd 9th 10th century found in Samarra.jpg| width1 = 131 | caption1 = | image2 =Iraqi earthen jar 9th century derived from Tang export wares.jpg| width2 = 150 | caption2 = |image3 =| width3 =| caption3 =}} {{multiple image| align = right | direction = horizontal | header = | header_align = left/right/center | footer = An example of reverse influence, with the adoption of an Islamic design in Chinese porcelain.
'''Left image''': Brass tray stand, [[Egypt]] or [[Syria]], in the name of [[Al-Nasir Muhammad|Muhammad ibn Qalaun]], 1330–40.[[British Museum]].
'''Right image''': Ming porcelain tray stand with [[Pseudo-Kufic|pseudo-arabic]] letters, 15th century, found in [[Damascus]]. [[British Museum]].| footer_align = left | image1 =Brass tray stand Egypt or Syria in the name of ibn Qalaun 1330 1340.jpg| width1 = 165 | caption1 = | image2 =Ming porcelain tray stand with pseudo arabic letters 15th century found in Damascus.jpg| width2 = 180 | caption2 = }} '''Chinese influences on [[Islamic pottery]]''' cover a period starting from at least the 8th century CE to the 19th century. This influence of [[Chinese ceramics]] has to be viewed in the broader context of the considerable importance of Chinese culture on [[Islamic art]]s in general. ==Earliest exchanges== ===Pre-Islamic contacts with Central Asia=== [[File:ZhouVase.JPG|thumb|left|[[Eastern Zhou]] vase, thought to incorporate Western influences (3rd–4th century BCE).]] Despite the distances involved, there is evidence of some contact between eastern and southwestern Asia from antiquity. Some very early Western influence on Chinese pottery seems to appear from the 3rd–4th century BCE. An [[Eastern Zhou]] red earthenware bowl, decorated with [[slip (ceramics)|slip]] and inlaid with glass paste, and now in the British Museum, is thought to have imitated metallic vessels, possibly of foreign origin. Foreign influence especially is thought to have encouraged the Eastern Zhou interest in glass decorations.British Museum, Ancient China permanent exhibit {{multiple image| align = right | direction = horizontal | header = | header_align = left/right/center | footer = '''Left image''': [[Northern Qi]] jar with [[Central Asian]], possibly [[Sogdiana|Sogdian]], dancer and musicians, 550–577.
'''Middle image''': Earthenware jar with Central Asian face, Northern Qi 550–577.
'''Right image''': Northern Qi earthenware with multicultural (Egyptian, Greek, Eurasian) motifs, 550–577.| footer_align = left | image1 =Northern Qi jar with olive green glaze with Central Asian dancer and musicians 550 577.jpg| width1 = 154 | caption1 = | image2 =Earthenware jar with green glaze Northern Qi 550 577.jpg| width2 = 146 | caption2 = |image3 =Northern Qi earthenware with multicultural motifs 550 to 577.jpg| width3 = 153 | caption3 =}} Contacts between [[China]] and [[Central Asia]] were formally opened from the 2nd to 1st century BCE through the [[Silk Road]]. In the following centuries, a great cultural influx benefited China, embodied by the appearance in China of foreign art, new ideas and religions (especially [[Buddhism]]), and new lifestyles. Artistic influences combined a multiplicity of cultures which had intermixed along the Silk Road, especially [[Hellenistic civilization|Hellenistic]], [[Ancient Egypt|Egyptian]], [[India]]n and [[Central Asian]] cultures, displaying a strong cosmopolitanism. Such mixed influences are especially visible in the earthenwares of Northern China in the 6th century, such as those of the [[Northern Qi]] (550–577) or the [[Northern Zhou]] (557–581). In that period, high quality high-fired earthenware starts to appear, called the "jeweled type", which incorporates [[Lotus Flower|lotuses]] from Buddhist art, as well as elements of [[Sasanian]] designs such as pearl roundels, lion masks or musicians and dancers.[https://books.google.com/books?id=Sz5KGNcs9xEC&pg=PA119 ''The arts of China'' by Michael Sullivan p.119''ff''] The best of these ceramics use bluish green, yellow or olive glazes. ===Early Islamic period=== [[File:Tang earthenware fragment with sancai glaze end of 7th early 8th century excavated in Nishapur Iran.jpg|thumb|[[Tang Dynasty]] earthenware fragment with ''[[sancai]]'' glaze, end of 7th-early 8th century, excavated in [[Nishapur]], [[Iran]].]] Direct contacts between the Muslim and Chinese worlds were marked by the [[Battle of Talas]] in 751 in [[Central Asia]]. Muslim communities are known to have been present in China as early as the 8th century CE, especially in commercial harbours such as [[Guangdong|Canton]] and [[Hangzhou]]. From the 9th century onwards, Islamic merchants started to import Chinese ceramics, which were at the core of the [[Indian Ocean]] luxury trade at that time.''Medieval Islamic civilization: an encyclopedia'' by Josef W. Meri, Jere L. Bacharach p.143 [https://books.google.com/books?id=MypbfKdMePIC&pg=PA143] These exotic objects were cherished in the [[Islamic world]] and also became an inspiration for local potters. Archaeological finds of [[Chinese pottery]] in the [[Middle East]] go back to the 8th century, starting with Chinese pottery of the [[Tang period]] (618–907). Remains of [[Tang dynasty|Tang period]] (618–907) ceramics have been found in [[Samarra]] and [[Ctesiphon]] in present-day [[Iraq]], as well as in [[Nishapur]] in present-day [[Iran]].Notice of the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]] permanent exhibition. These include porcelaneous white wares from Northern Chinese kilns, celadon-glazed stoneware originating in the [[State of Yue|Yue]] kilns of Northern [[Zhejiang]], and the splashed stoneware of [[Changsha Tongguan Kiln Site|Changsha kilns]] in [[Hunan Province]].[https://books.google.com/books?id=TV6f2XWG6t4C&pg=PA68 ''Maritime silk road'' Qingxin Li p.68] Chinese pottery was the object of gift-making in Islamic lands: the Islamic writer Muhammad Ibn-al-Husain-Bahaki wrote in 1059 that [[Ali ibn Isa ibn Mahan|Ali Ibn Isa]], the governor of [[Greater Khorasan|Khurasan]], presented [[Harun al-Rashid]], the Caliph, twenty pieces of Chinese imperial porcelain, the like of which had never been at a caliph's court before, in addition to 2,000 other pieces of porcelain".''Studies in Chinese ceramics'' by Dekun Zheng, Cheng Te-K'Un p.90''ff'' [https://books.google.com/books?id=3die4xQmNzQC&pg=PA90] ===Yuan and Ming dynasties=== [[File:Early blue and white ware circa 1335 Jingdezhen.jpg|thumb|Early Chinese [[blue and white porcelain]], c 1335, early [[Yuan dynasty]], [[Jingdezhen]], using a Middle-eastern shape]] By the time of the [[Mongol invasion of China]] a considerable export trade westwards to the Islamic world was established, and Islamic attempts to imitate Chinese porcelain in their own [[fritware]] bodies had begun in the 12th century. These were less successful than those of [[Korean pottery]], but eventually were able to provide attractive local competition to Chinese imports.Vainker, Ch. 5, pp. 134, 140–141 especially Chinese production could adapt to the preferences of foreign markets; larger [[celadon]] dishes than the Chinese market wanted were favoured for serving princely banquets in the Middle East. Celadon wares were believed there to have the ability to detect poison, by sweating or breaking.Vainker, 136–137 After about 1450 celadon wares fell out of fashion in China, and the continuing production, of lower quality, was for export. The Islamic market was apparently especially important in the early years of [[Chinese blue and white porcelain]], which appears to have been mainly exported until the Ming; it was called "Muslim blue" by the Chinese. Again, large dishes were an export style, and the densely painted decoration of Yuan blue and white borrowed heavily from the [[arabesque]]s and [[scroll (art)|plant scrolls]] of Islamic decoration, probably mostly taking the style from metalwork examples, which also provided shapes for some vessels. This style of ornament was then confined to blue and white, and is not found in the red and white painted wares then preferred by the Chinese themselves. The [[cobalt blue]] that was used was itself imported from Persia, and the export trade in porcelain was handled by colonies of Muslim merchants in [[Quanzhou]], convenient for the huge [[Jingdezhen]] potteries, and other ports to the south.Vainker, 137–140; Clunas and Harrison-Hall, 86–95 The start of the [[Ming dynasty]] was quickly followed by a decree of 1368, forbidding trade with foreign countries. This was not entirely successful, and had to be repeated several times, and the giving of lavish imperial diplomatic gifts continued, concentrating on silk and porcelain (19,000 pieces of porcelain in 1383), but it severely set back the export trade. The policy was relaxed under the next emperor after 1403, but had by then greatly stimulated the production of pottery emulating Chinese styles in the Islamic world itself, which was by now reaching a high level of quality in several countries (high enough to fool contemporary Europeans in many cases).Vainker, 140–142 Often Islamic production imitated not the latest Chinese styles, but those of the late Yuan and early Ming.Vainker, 140–141 In turn, Chinese potters began in the early 16th century to produce some items in overtly Islamic styles, including jumbled inscriptions in Arabic. These appear to have been made for the growing Chinese Muslim market, and probably those at court wishing to keep up with the [[Zhengde Emperor]]'s (r. 1505–1521) flirtation with Islam.Vainker, 142–143 ==Evolution== ===Yue ware=== {{further|Yue ware}} [[File:Tang Dynasty stoneware with celadon glaze ie Yue ware found in Samarra Iraq.jpg|thumb|[[Tang Dynasty]] stoneware with [[celadon]] [[Ceramic glaze|glaze]] (Yue ware), found in [[Samarra]], [[Iraq]].]] Yue ware originated in the [[State of Yue|Yue]] kilns of Northern [[Zhejiang]], in the site of [[Jiyuan]] near [[Shaoxing]], called "Yuezhou" (越州) in ancient times.[https://books.google.com/books?id=sn0CyBCJKz8C&pg=PA90 ''The arts of China'' by Michael Sullivan p.90''ff''] Yue ware was first manufactured from the 2nd century CE, when it consisted in some very precise imitations of [[bronze]] vessels, many of which were found in tombs of the [[Nanjing]] region. After this initial phase, Yue ware evolved progressively into true ceramic form, and became a true medium of artistic expression.''Chinese glazes: their origins, chemistry, and recreation'' Nigel Wood p.35''ff'' [https://books.google.com/books?id=NGw8DUuNywYC&pg=PA35] Production in Jiyuan stopped in the 6th century, but expanded to various areas of Zhejiang, especially around the shores of Shanglinhu in Yuyaoxian. Yue ware was highly valued, and was used as tribute for the imperial court in northern China in the 9th century. Significantly, it was also used in China's most revered [[Famen Temple]] in [[Shaanxi Province]]. Yue ware was exported to the [[Middle East]] early on, and shards of Yue ware have been excavated in [[Samarra]], [[Iraq]], in an early example of Chinese influences on Islamic pottery, as well as to [[East Asia]] and [[South Asia]] as well as [[East Africa]] from the 8th to the 11th century. ===Sancai ware=== {{further|Sancai}} {{multiple image| align = right | direction = horizontal | header = | header_align = left/right/center | footer = '''Left image''': Chinese Tang lobed dish 9–10th century. [[British Museum]].
'''Right image''': Iraqi lobed dish inspired from Tang examples, 9–10th century. [[British Museum]].| footer_align = left | image1 =Chinese Tang lobed dish 9th 10th century.jpg| width1 = 182 | caption1 = | image2 =Iraqi lobed dish inspired from Tang examples 9th 10th century.jpg | width2 = 165 | caption2 = }} [[File:Tang sancai vase 8th 9th century.jpg|thumb|Tang ''[[sancai]]'' vase displaying Central Asian and Persian influence. 8–9th century. [[Guimet Museum]].]] [[Tang period]] earthenware shards with low-fired [[polychrome]] three-color ''[[sancai]]'' glazes from the 9th century were exported to Middle-Eastern countries such as [[Iraq]] and [[Egypt]], and have been excavated in [[Samarra]] in present-day [[Iraq]] and in [[Nishapur]] in present-day [[Iran]].''Chinese glazes: their origins, chemistry, and recreation'' Nigel Wood p.205''ff'' [https://books.google.com/books?id=NGw8DUuNywYC&pg=PA206] These Chinese styles were soon adopted for local [[Middle-Eastern]] manufactures. Copies were made by Iraqi craftsmen as soon as the 9th century CE.Notice of [[British Museum]] "Islamic Art Room" permanent exhibit.[https://books.google.com/books?id=ba3LyiGfPU8C&pg=PA41 ''Islamic art'' by Barbara Brend p.41] In order to imitate Chinese ''Sancai'', lead glazes were used on top of vessels coated with white [[Slip (ceramics)|slip]] and a colorless glaze. The coloured lead glazes were then splashed on the surface, where they spread and mixed, according to the [[slipware]] technique. Shapes were also imitated, such as the lobed dishes found in Chinese Tang ceramics and silverware which were reproduced in Iraq during the 9–10th century. Conversely, numerous Central Asian and Persian influences were at work in the designs of Chinese ''sancai'' wares: pictures of Central Asian mounted warriors, scenes representing Central Asian musicians, vases in the shape of Middle-Eastern [[ewer]]s. File:Bowl 9th 10th century Iran.jpg|[[Iran]] three-color ceramic, 9-10th century. Image:SyrianCeramic13thCentury.jpg|[[Syrian]] three-color ceramic, 13th century. Image:CyprusGlazedCeramic14thCentury.jpg|Three-color glazed ceramics, [[Cyprus]], 14th century. ===White ware=== {{further|Tin-glazed pottery}} [[File:Chinese white ware and Iraqi earthenware bowls 9th 10th century both found in Iraq.jpg|thumb|left|Chinese white ware bowl found in [[Iran]] (left), and earthenware bowl found in al-Mina (Turkey) (right), both 9–10th century. [[British Museum]].]] [[File:Chinese white ware dish 9th found in Iran and stone paste dish made in Iran 12th century.jpg|thumb|left|Chinese white ware dish (left), 9th century, found in Iran, and a [[stone-paste]] dish made in Iran (right), 12th century.]] [[File:Islamic pottery with turpuoise glaze and fish motif in imitation of Chinese celadon ware probably Iran 14th century.jpg|thumb|left|Islamic pottery with turquoise glaze and fish motif, in imitation of Chinese [[celadon]] ware, probably [[Iran]], 14th century.]] Soon after the sancai period, Chinese white ware ceramics also found their way to the [[Islamic world]], and were immediately reproduced. The Chinese white ware was actually [[porcelain]], invented in the 9th century, and used [[kaolin]] and high-temperature firing, but Islamic workshops were unable to duplicate its manufacture. Instead, they manufactured fine earthenware bowls with the desired shape, and covered them with a white glaze rendered [[Opacity (optics)|opaque]] by the addition of [[tin]], an early example of [[tin-glazing]]. The Chinese shapes were also reproduced, seemingly to pass for China-made wares. In the 12th century, Islamic manufacturers further developed [[stone-paste]] techniques in order to obtain hard bodies approximating the hardness obtained by Chinese porcelain. This technique was used until the 18th century, when the Europeans discovered the Chinese technique for high-firing porcelain clays. ===Celadon ware=== The Chinese fashion for greenware, or [[celadon]], ware was also transmitted to the Islamic world, where it gave rise to productions using [[turquoise]] glazing and fish motifs identical to the ones used in China. ===Blue and white ware=== {{further|Blue and white porcelain|İznik pottery}} {{multiple image| align = right | direction = horizontal | header = | header_align = left/right/center | footer = '''Left image''': Ming plate with grape design, 15th century, [[Jingdezhen]] kilns, [[Jiangxi]]. [[British Museum]].
'''Right image''': Stone-paste dish with grape design, [[Iznik]], [[Turkey]], 1550–70. [[British Museum]].| footer_align = left | image1 =Ming plate 15th century Jingdezhen kilns Jiangxi.jpg| width1 = 172 | caption1 = | image2 =Stone paste dish Iznik Turkey 1550 1570.JPG| width2 = 175 | caption2 = }} The technique of [[cobalt blue]] decorations seems to have been invented in the Middle East in the 9th century through decorative experimentation on white ware, and the technique of blue-and-white ware was developed in China in the 14th century.[http://www.encyclopedia.com/topic/porcelain.aspx Porcelain. ''Columbia Encyclopedia''] On some occasions, Chinese blue and white wares also incorporated Islamic designs, as in the case of some Mamluk brass works which were converted into blue and white Chinese porcelain designs. Chinese blue and white ware then became extremely popular in the Middle East, where both Chinese and Islamic types coexisted. From the 13th century, Chinese pictorial designs, such as flying [[Crane (bird)|cranes]], [[dragons]] and [[lotus flowers]] also started to appear in the ceramic productions of the Near East, especially in [[Syria]] and [[Egypt]]. [[File:Ming incense burner 1575 1600 with Ottoman mount 1618.jpg|thumb|[[Ming Dynasty]] [[incense burner]] (1575–1600) with [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] metallic mount dated 1618. [[Turkish and Islamic Arts Museum]].]] Chinese porcelain of the 14th or 15th century was transmitted to the [[Middle East]] and the [[Near East]], and especially to the [[Ottoman Empire]] either through gifts or through war [[Looting|booty]]. Chinese designs were extremely influential with the pottery manufacturers at [[Iznik]], [[Turkey]]. The Ming "grape" design in particular was highly popular and was extensively reproduced under the Ottoman Empire. The style of Persian pottery known as [[Kubachi ware]] also absorbed influence from China, imitating both celadons and Ming blue-and-white porcelain. ==See also== *[[Silk Road]] *[[Islamic contributions to Medieval Europe]] ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==References== *[[Craig Clunas|Clunas, Craig]] and Harrison-Hall, Jessica, ''Ming: 50 years that changed China'', 2014, British Museum Press, {{ISBN|9780714124841}} *Vainker, S.J., ''Chinese Pottery and Porcelain'', 1991, British Museum Press, 9780714114705 ==Further reading== *Canby, Sheila R. (ed). ''Shah Abbas; The Remaking of Iran'', 2009, British Museum Press, {{ISBN|9780714124520}} *{{cite book|last1=Crowe|first1=Yolande|title=Persia and China: Safavid Blue and White Ceramics in the Victoria and Albert Museum 1501–1738|date=2002|publisher=La Borie|location=London|isbn=978-0953819614 }} *{{cite book | author=Rawson, Jessica | title=Chinese Ornament: The Lotus and the Dragon | location=London | publisher=British Museum Publications Ltd | year=1984 | isbn=978-0714114316 }} *{{cite book | author=Wilkinson, Charles K. | title=Nishapur: pottery of the early Islamic period |url=http://libmma.contentdm.oclc.org/cdm/compoundobject/collection/p15324coll10/id/93805 | location=New York | publisher=The Metropolitan Museum of Art | year=1973 | isbn=0870990764 }} ==External links== *[http://libmma.contentdm.oclc.org/cdm/compoundobject/collection/p15324coll10/id/38422/rec/3 A Handbook of Chinese Ceramics] from The Metropolitan Museum of Art Libraries {{Porcelain}} [[Category:History of ceramics]] [[Category:Chinese porcelain]] [[Category:Islamic art]] [[Category:Iranian pottery]] [[Category:Islamic pottery]] [[Category:Multiculturalism and Islam]]

revision.comment: /* Overview */ reference was present, removed the call for a citation
revision.text:
'''Cognitive synonymy''' is a type of [[synonym]]y in which synonyms are so similar in [[meaning (linguistics)|meaning]] that they cannot be differentiated either [[denotation|denotatively]] or [[connotation|connotatively]], that is, not even by [[association of ideas|mental associations]], [[connotation]]s, emotive responses, and [[poetry|poetic value]]. It is a stricter (more precise) technical definition of synonymy, specifically for theoretical (e.g., [[linguistics|linguistic]] and [[philosophical]]) purposes. In [[usage]] employing this definition, synonyms with greater differences are often called near-synonyms rather than synonyms.<ref name="Stanojević_2009">{{Citation |last=Stanojević |first=Maja |year=2009 |title= Cognitive synonymy: a general overview |journal=Facta Universitatis, Linguistics and Literature series |volume=7 |issue=2 |pages=193-200 |url=http://facta.junis.ni.ac.rs/lal/lal200902/lal200902-05.pdf |doi= |postscript=.}}</ref>
==Overview== If a word is cognitively synonymous with another word, they refer to the same thing independently of [[context (language use)|context]]. Thus, a word is cognitively synonymous with another word [[if and only if]] all instances of both words express the same exact thing, and the referents are [[modal logic|necessarily]] [[identity (philosophy)|identical]], which means that the words' interchangeability is not [[wikt:context-sensitive|context-sensitive]].
[[Willard Van Orman Quine]] used the concept of cognitive synonymy extensively in his famous 1951 paper "[[Two Dogmas of Empiricism]]", where two words were cognitively synonymous if they were interchangeable in every possible instance.<ref name="Hanna_2005">{{Citation |last=Hanna |first=Patricia |year=2005 |title=''Cognitive Synonymy'', from Notes on "Two Dogmas of Empiricism" |url=http://www.hum.utah.edu/~phanna/classes/ling5030/webpostings/notestwodogmas/node14.html |postscript=.}}</ref><ref name="">{{Citation |last=Quine |first=Willard Van Orman |year=1951 |title=Two dogmas of empiricism |journal=The Philosophical Review |volume=60 |issue= |pages=20–43 |url=http://www.ditext.com/quine/quine.html |doi= |postscript=. Reprinted in his 1953 book ''From a Logical Point of View''. Harvard University Press.}}</ref>
For example, * All bachelors are unmarried men. * All unmarried men are not married.
Quine notes that if one is [[use-mention distinction|referring to the word itself]], this doesn't apply, as in, * ''Bachelor'' has fewer than ten letters.
As compared to the substitution which is obviously false, * "Unmarried men" has less than ten letters.
==See also== * [[A priori and a posteriori|A priori]] * [[Analytic-synthetic distinction]] * [[Empiricism]] * [[Association of Ideas|Mental association]] * [[Quotation]] * [[Synonym ring]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== * Cappelen, Herman and Ernest LePore, [http://plato.stanford.edu/archives/win2008/entries/quotation/ Quotation], The Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy (Winter 2008 Edition), Edward N. Zalta (ed.).
[[Category:Philosophy of language]] [[Category:Empiricism]] [[Category:Epistemology]] [[Category:Cognition]] [[Category:Analytic philosophy]] [[Category:Willard Van Orman Quine]]
{{epistemology-stub}}

In [[genre studies]], a '''coming-of-age story''' is a [[genre]] of [[literature]] and [[film]] that focuses on the growth of a [[protagonist]] from youth to adulthood ("[[coming of age]]"). Coming-of-age stories tend to emphasize dialogue or internal monologue over action, and are often set in the past. The subjects of coming-of-age stories are typically teenagers.<ref name=Benyahia /> The [[Bildungsroman]] is a specific subgenre of coming-of-age story.
==In literature== * The ''[[Telemachy]]'' in [[Homer]]'s ''[[Odyssey]]'' (8th century BC) * ''[[Hayy ibn Yaqdhan]]'', by [[Ibn Tufail]] (12th century)<ref>{{Cite book|title=Fifty major thinkers on education: from Confucius to Dewey|last=Joy Palmer, Liora Bresler|first=David Edward Cooper|publisher=[[Routledge]]|year=2001|isbn=0-415-23126-4|page=34}}</ref> * ''[[The History of Tom Jones, a Foundling]]'', by [[Henry Fielding]] (1749)<ref name="McWilliams2009p14" /> * ''[[The Life and Opinions of Tristram Shandy, Gentleman]]'', by [[Laurence Sterne]] (1759)<ref name="McWilliams2009p14">{{cite book|last=McWilliams|first=Ellen |title=Margaret Atwood and the Female Bildungsroman|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=q2GuhQCODeMC&pg=PA14|year=2009|publisher=Ashgate Publishing, Ltd.|isbn=978-0-7546-6027-9|page=14|quote=The two early English Bildungsromane already mentioned, ''Tom Jones'' and ''The Life and Opinions of Tristram Shandy'', are examples of coming-of-age narratives that predate the generic expectations of the German tradition.}}</ref> * ''[[Candide]]'', by [[Voltaire]] (1759) * ''[[Northanger Abbey]]'', by [[Jane Austen]] (1817) * '' [[A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man]]'' by [[James Joyce]] (1916)<ref>{{cite web|last1=Knausgård|first1=Karl|authorlink=Karl Ove Knausgård|title=On Reading ''Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man''|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/24/magazine/on-reading-portrait-of-the-artist-as-a-young-man.html|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=28 May 2016}}</ref> * ''[[A Tree Grows in Brooklyn (novel)|A Tree Grows in Brooklyn]]'', by [[Betty Smith]] (1943) * ''[[The Catcher in the Rye]]'', by [[J. D. Salinger]] (1951)
* ''[[To Kill a Mockingbird]]'', (novel) by [[Harper Lee]] (1960)
* ''[[The Bell Jar]]'', by [[Sylvia Plath]] (1964) * ''[[A Day No Pigs Would Die]]'', by [[Robert Newton Peck]] (1972) * ''[[Into the Widening World]]'', a collection of 26 short fictional coming-of-age stories by 26 notable authors (published 1995) * ''[[The Perks of Being a Wallflower]]'', by [[Stephen Chbosky]] (1999) * ''[[Five Point Someone]]'', by [[Chetan Bhagat]] (2004) * ''[[The Name of the Wind]]'' and the rest of The Kingkiller Chronicles by [[Patrick Rothfuss]] (2007–present) * ''[[Simon vs. the Homo Sapiens Agenda]]'' by [[Becky Albertalli]] (2015).
=={{anchor|In film}} In film and TV== {{refimprove section|date=October 2017}} In film, coming of age is a genre of [[teen film]]s. Coming-of-age films focus on the psychological and moral growth or transition of a [[protagonist]] from [[youth]] to adulthood. Personal growth and change is an important characteristic of this genre, which relies on dialogue and emotional responses, rather than action. The main character is typically male, around mid-teen and the story is often told in the form of a flashback.<ref name=Benyahia>{{cite book |author1=Benyahia, Sarah Casey |author2=Gaffney, Freddie |author3=White, John | title=As Film Studies: The Essential Introduction | series=Essentials Series | isbn=0-415-39311-6 | publisher=Taylor & Francis | year=2006 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-pyveRuwHzsC&pg=PA271 | accessdate=5 May 2011 }}</ref>
Films in this subgenre include ''[[Bambi]]'' (1942), ''[[The Apu Trilogy]]'' (1955{{ndash}}1959), ''[[The 400 Blows|Les 400 Coups]]'' (1959), ''[[Oliver!]]'' (1967), ''[[American Graffiti]]'' (1973), ''[[Breaking Away]]'' (1979), ''[[The Last American Virgin]]'' (1982), ''[[Mischief (film)|Mischief]]'' (1985), ''[[The Breakfast Club]]'' (1985), ''[[Fandango (1985 film)|Fandango]]'' (1985), ''[[Stand by Me (film)|Stand by Me]]'' (1986), ''[[Empire of the Sun (film)|Empire of the Sun]]'' (1987), ''[[Stealing Home]]'' (1988), ''[[Mermaids (1990 film)|Mermaids]]'' (1990), ''[[Dazed and Confused (film)|Dazed and Confused]]'' (1993), ''[[Almost Famous]]'' (2000), ''[[Spirited Away]]'' (2001), ''[[Y Tu Mamá También]]'' (2001), ''[[The Motorcycle Diaries (film)|The Motorcycle Diaries]]'' (2003), ''[[Lakshya (film)|Lakshya]]'' (2004), ''[[Juno (film)|Juno]]'' (2007), ''[[The Reader (2008 film)|The Reader]]'' (2008), the ''[[Harry Potter (film series)|Harry Potter]]'' series (2001–2011), [[Moonrise Kingdom]] (2012), ''[[The Perks of Being a Wallflower (film)|The Perks of Being a Wallflower]]'' (2012), ''[[The Kings of Summer]]'' (2013), ''[[The Spectacular Now]]'' (2013), ''[[Boyhood (film)|Boyhood]]'' (2014), which was filmed with the same cast over a period of twelve years, ''[[Me and Earl and the Dying Girl (film)|Me and Earl and the Dying Girl]]'' (2015), ''[[Sleeping Giant (film)|Sleeping Giant]]'' (2015), [[The Edge of Seventeen]]'' (2016), [[Moonlight (2016 film)|''Moonlight'']] (2016), ''[[Spider-Man: Homecoming]]'' (2017), ''[[It (2017 film)|It]]'' (2017), ''[[Lady Bird (film)|Lady Bird]]'' (2017), ''[[Call Me by Your Name (film)|Call Me by Your Name]]'' (2017), ''[[Love, Simon]]'' (2018), ''[[Eighth Grade (film)|Eighth Grade]]'' (2018), and ''[[To All the Boys I've Loved Before (film)|To All the Boys I’ve Loved Before]]'' (2018).
Films featuring protagonists in particular age groups, such as pre-teens, are ''[[The Sandlot]]'' (1993) and ''[[My Girl (film)|My Girl]]'' (1991), or high school graduates and college students, in films such as ''[[With Honors (film)|With Honors]]'' (1994), ''[[American Pie (film)|American Pie]]'' (1999), ''[[Can't Hardly Wait]]'' (1998), ''[[Spider-Man 2]]'' (2004), ''[[Superbad (film)|Superbad]]'' (2007), ''[[An Education]]'' and ''[[3 Idiots]]'' (2009).
Coming of age television series include ''[[Happy Days]]'' (1974-1984),<ref name=Fox>{{cite web | first=Levi | last=Fox | year=2002 | title=The Historical Coming of Age Genre | work=Were Those the Days? Historical Coming of Age Films in American Culture | publisher=American Studies, University of Virginia | url=http://xroads.virginia.edu/~ug02/fox/genre.html | accessdate=5 May 2011 }}</ref> the ''[[Degrassi (franchise)|Degrassi]]'' franchise (1979–present),''[[The Wonder Years]]'' (1988-1993),<ref name=Fox /> ''[[Boy Meets World]]'' (1993-2000), ''[[Daria]]'' (1997-2001), ''[[Freaks and Geeks]]'' (1999-2000), ''[[Skins (UK TV series)|Skins]]'' (2007-2013), ''[[Glee (TV series)|Glee]]'' (2009-2015), ''[[Teen Wolf (2011 TV series)|Teen Wolf]]'' (2011-2017), ''[[Steven Universe]]'' (2013–present), ''[[Over the Garden Wall]]'' (2014), ''[[Girl Meets World]]'' (2014-2017), ''[[Skam (TV series)|Skam]]'' (2015-2017), ''[[Stranger Things]]'' (2016–present), ''[[13 Reasons Why]]'' (2017–present), ''[[One Day at a Time (2017 TV series)|One Day at a Time]]'' (2017–present), ''[[On My Block (TV series)|On My Block]]'' (2018–present), and ''[[SKAM Austin]]'' (2018–present).
==In gaming== In gaming, this sub-genre includes: ''[[Life is Strange]]''.
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Young adult development}} {{film genres}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Coming Of Age Story}} [[Category:Coming-of-age fiction| ]] [[Category:Film genres]] [[Category:Literary genres]]

{{Infobox company | name = Comme des Garçons | logo = [[Image:CommeDesGarcons.jpg|200px|Comme des Garçons]] | type = Private Company | caption = | foundation = {{start date and age|1969}} | location = [[Paris, France]] | key_people = [[Rei Kawakubo]], founder and designer
[[Junya Watanabe]], designer
Tao Kurihara, designer
Fumito Ganryu, designer
Adrian Joffe, [[CEO]] | num_employees = 800 est. (2011) | industry = [[Fashion]] | products = [[Apparel]], [[Fashion accessory|Accessories]] and [[Perfumes]] | operating profit = | homepage = [http://www.doverstreetmarket.com www.doverstreetmarket.com] [http://www.cdgmelb.com] [http://comme-des-garcons-parfum.com www.comme-des-garcons-parfum.com] [http://www.comme-des-garcons.com www.comme-des-garcons.com] [http://comme-des-garcons.spb.ru www.comme-des-garcons.spb.ru] }} '''Comme des Garçons''' is a [[Japan]]ese fashion label founded by and headed by [[Rei Kawakubo]]. It is based in [[Tokyo]] and also in the [[Place Vendôme]] in [[Paris]], the city in which they show their main collections during Paris Fashion Week and Paris Men's Fashion Week.http://www.elle.com/fashion/a33802/rei-kawakubo-interview/ The Japanese flagship store is in [[Aoyama, Tokyo|Aoyama]], Tokyo's high fashion district. The company also has concept stores Trading Museum Comme des Garçons and 10 Corso Como Comme des Garçons in Tokyo, and stores in [[Kyoto]], [[Osaka]] and [[Fukuoka]]. Worldwide they have traditional Comme des Garçons stores in [[Rue du Faubourg Saint-Honoré|Rue du Faubourg St-Honoré]] in [[Paris]] and on West 22nd Street in [[New York City]], as well as stores in [[Hong Kong]], [[Beijing]], [[Bangkok]], [[Seoul]], [[Singapore]], [[Melbourne]] and [[Manila]]. Since 2004, Comme des Garçons has developed a market-based department store concept, stocking its main collections, its other brands, such as ''Shirt'', ''Play'', and a wide range of international designers. Its original market store, called [[Dover Street Market]], is in [[London]]. In 2010, the company opened [[I.T]] [[Beijing]] Market Comme des Garçons, which was followed by a new market store in Ginza, [[Tokyo]], in 2012 and [[New York City]] in 2013, as well as Berlin more recently.http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2005/07/04/the-misfit-3 ==History== [[File:Comme des Garcons dress Florence Italy 2007.jpg|thumb|Comme des Garçons dress on display in 2007 in a Florence, Italy museum]] [[File:Comme des Garcons men for H&M 09.jpg|thumb|Comme des Garçons for [[H&M]] [[tuxedo]] jacket, 2009]] The label was started in [[Tokyo]] by [[Rei Kawakubo]] in 1969 and established as a company '''Comme des Garçons Co. Ltd''' in 1973. It is written in Japanese as コム・デ・ギャルソン (''Komu de Gyaruson'').{{cite web|title=Company Overview of Comme Des Garcons Co., Ltd. |url=http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=5663541 |publisher=Bloomberg BusinessWeek |accessdate=2014-02-24}} It became successful in Japan in the 1970s; a menswear line was added in 1978. The year 1981 saw Comme des Garçons's debut show in Paris. It created a splash for its predominant use of black and distressed fabrics.{{cite news|author=iPad iPhone Android TIME TV Populist The Page |url=http://www.time.com/time/2004/style/020904/power/9.html |title=Women in fashion – Rei Kawakubo |publisher=Time magazine |date= |accessdate=2013-09-24}} Throughout the 1980s, Comme des Garçons's clothes often were associated with a 'distressed' and 'punk' oriented style. Comme des Garçons's designer fashion lines are designed and [[Manufacturing in Japan|produced in Japan]]. Lines including ''Comme des Garçons Comme des Garçons, Comme des Garçons Noir, Comme des Garçons Homme, Comme des Garçons Honme Plus, Comme des Garçons Man, Comme des Garçons Deux and Comme des Garçons Shirt'', are all handmade. This is because Comme des Garçons adamantly values the quality of hand-made garments, reflected in the more expensive price and longevity of their products. Play, the company's luxury casual streetwear line, is mainly produced in Japan, Spain, and Turkey, with France's Play factory still utilizing many hand-made procedures as opposed to Japan, Spain, and Turkey's production line factory. This is because France's factory also produces hand-made only lines, including ''Tricot Comme des Garçons, Comme des Garçons Homme Plus Evergreen, and Junya Watanabe Comme Des Garçons''. It is believed that all [[fabric]]s are produced in Japan, but some China and Australia sold pieces are hand-finished in France for quality control purposes (distinguishable by the hand stitched heart emblem). In an article for ''Business of Fashion'' in April 2017, Tim Blanks reported generated revenue for CDG and its affiliates as "over $280 million a year".Tim Blanks. ''Business of Fashion''. "A Punk's Pain". April 24, 2017. [https://www.businessoffashion.com/articles/people/rei-kawakubo-interview-commes-des-garcons-metropolitan-museum-of-art]. ==Fashion== Comme des Garçons collections are designed in the Comme des Garçons studio in [[Aoyama, Tokyo]] and are manufactured in Japan, France, Spain, and Turkey. The company has over the years recurrently associated itself with the arts and cultural projects internationally. The 1997 spring-summer collection, often referred to the "lumps and bumps" collection, which contained fabric in bulk and balls on the garments. This led to a collaboration, also in 1997, between [[Rei Kawakubo]] and New York-based choreographer [[Merce Cunningham]] called "Scenario". The 2006 autumn/winter collection dealt with the concept of the "persona",{{cite web|author=Sarah Mower |url=http://www.style.com/fashionshows/collections/F2006RTW/review/CMMEGRNS |title=Comme des Garçons F/W 2006 |publisher=style.com |date=2006-03-04 |accessdate=2013-09-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080718164130/http://www.style.com/fashionshows/collections/F2006RTW/review/CMMEGRNS |archivedate=2008-07-18 |df= }} the different ways we present ourselves to the world. Fusing tailored menswear with more feminine elements such as corsets and flower printed dress fabrics, "Persona" was another collection that combined the feminine with the masculine by Comme des Garçons. [[Junya Watanabe]]{{cite web|url=http://nymag.com/fashion/fashionshows/designers/bios/junyawatanabe/ |title=Junya Watanabe |publisher=NYmag |date= |accessdate=2013-09-24}}{{cite web|author1=Mari Davis |author2=Tom Massey |author3=Boyd Davis |url=http://www.fashionwindows.com/beauty/junya_watanabe/default.asp |title=Junya Watanabe |publisher=Fashion Windows |date= |accessdate=2013-09-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130630213611/http://www.fashionwindows.com/beauty/junya_watanabe/default.asp |archivedate=June 30, 2013 }} and, as of recently, Tao Kurihara{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/fashion/features/tao-kurihara-the-end-of-an-era-2269186.html |title=Gentle maverick Tao Kurihara's autumn collection will be the last under her own name. She explains her change of direction to Susannah Frankel |publisher=Independent.co.uk}}[http://www.liberty.co.uk/what_s_in_store/womenswear/designer_room/343 Liberty: Designer Room] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080414204529/http://www.liberty.co.uk/what_s_in_store/womenswear/designer_room/343 |date=April 14, 2008 }} have started their own sub-labels under the Comme des Garçons name to much acclaim. Both also were involved in designing for the casual women's knitwear line "Comme des Garçons Tricot". [[File:Comme des Garçons dress in red, white and blue.jpg|thumb|left|200px|Comme des Garçons dress]] Comme des Garçons have collaborated with various other labels over the years including Fred Perry, [[Levi's]] Converse All Star, [[Speedo]], [[Nike, Inc.|Nike]], [[Moncler]], [[Lacoste]], [[Cutler and Gross]], Chrome Hearts, Hammerthor,[http://www.vmagazine.com/blog.php?n=3082 vmagazine.com Comme des Garçons and the most avant-garde underwear around] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080123205530/http://www.vmagazine.com/blog.php?n=3082 |date=January 23, 2008 }} S. N. S. Herning, [[Louis Vuitton]], [[Supreme (clothing)|Supreme]], and many others. Comme des Garçons and [[H&M]] collaborated on a collection which was released in the fall of 2008.{{cite web|url=http://www.vogue.co.uk/news/daily/2008-04/080403-comme-des-garcons-for-handm.aspx |title=Comme des Garcons for H&M |publisher=Vogue |date=2008-04-03 |accessdate=2013-09-24}}{{cite web|last=Wells |first=Pete |url=http://www.iht.com/articles/2008/04/07/style/fcomme.php |title=Rei Kawakubo and H & M: A collaboration to watch |publisher=International Herald Tribune |date=2013-09-17 |accessdate=2013-09-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081204064315/http://www.iht.com/articles/2008/04/07/style/fcomme.php |archivedate=December 4, 2008 }} Notably, [[Björk]] wears Comme des Garçons in the music video for "[[Isobel (song)|Isobel]]". Other celebrities who have worn Comme des Garçons include [[Lady Gaga]], [[Matt Bellamy]], [[Alexander McQueen]], Krikor Jabotian, [[Chloë Sevigny]], [[Kanye West]], [[Usher (entertainer)|Usher]], [[Tilda Swinton]], [[Herb Ritts]], [[Tatiana Sorokko]], [[Karl Lagerfeld]], [[Heidi Albertsen]], [[Mary-Kate Olsen]], [[Vincent Ng]], [[Selma Blair]], Leila Aldik, [[Drake (entertainer)|Drake]], [[Joe Jonas]], [[Ellen DeGeneres]], [[ASAP Rocky]], [[2 Chainz]], Frank Ocean who devoted a song to and her. [[John Waters (filmmaker)|John Waters]], who devoted a chapter of his 2010 book ''Role Models'' to Comme des Garçons and Rei Kawakubo. Swedish musician [[Jonna Lee (singer)|Jonna Lee]] collaborated with Comms des Garçons in the creation of her audiovisual album ''Everyone Afraid to Be Forgotten'', where the fashion house designed the costumes for the film. ==Exhibitions== After the Paris début, Comme des Garçons exhibited photographs by [[Peter Lindbergh]] at the [[Centre Georges Pompidou]] in Paris in 1986.[http://www.peterlindbergh.net/exhibitions.html#1986 "Peter Lindbergh for Comme des Garçons"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080513233521/http://www.peterlindbergh.net/exhibitions.html#1986 |date=May 13, 2008 }} In 1990, they held an exhibition of sculpture. The year 2005 saw an exhibition in [[Shinjuku, Tokyo|Shinjuku]], Tokyo of Comme Des Garçons advertising and graphic designs. In August 2010, Comme des Garçons opened a {{convert|19000|sqft|m2}}, six-level flagship store in [[Seoul]], [[South Korea]], featuring a branded art-exhibition space, the company's first outside Japan.{{cite web|url=http://hypebeast.com/2010/09/comme-des-garcons-seoul-flagship-store |title=Comme des Garçons Seoul Flagship Store |publisher=Hypebeast |date=2010-09-01 |accessdate=2013-09-24}} == Comme Des Garçons Play == Commonly known for its heart-shaped logo with two eyes, Comme Des Garçons Play is Comme Des Garçons' casual luxury line. It is a more accessible variation of Comme Des Garcons's other lines. Directed at the younger market, Play is Comme Des Garcon's best selling clothes line. After Play made its debut on celebrities such as [[Kanye West]], [[Pharrell Williams|Pharell Williams]], and [[Justin Timberlake]],{{Cite news|url=https://www.hervia.com/blog/celebrity-spotted-comme-des-garcons-play/|title=Celebrity Spotted; Look Who Has Been Wearing Comme Des Garcons PLAY|work=Hervia|access-date=2017-03-19|language=en-US}} Play introduced collaborations with Nike, Jordan, Supreme, and Louis Vuitton,{{Cite web|url=https://hypebeast.com/tags/comme-des-garcons|title=Comme des Garcons {{!}} HYPEBEAST|website=hypebeast.com|language=en|access-date=2017-03-19}} and was quickly viewed as a prominent international fashion brand. Nowadays, Comme Des Garçons is mainly recognized for the heart-eyes logo found on Play pieces. ''Dover Street Market Group'' primarily carries Play products as opposed to those from Comme Des Garçons's more high-end lines. ==Perfume== Comme des Garçons also produces a line of agendered [[perfume|fragrances]], most of which are unconventional in the world of perfume, in the same spirit as the label's garments.{{cite web|last=Wells |first=Pete |url=http://www.iht.com/articles/2007/10/15/style/FPERFUME.php |title=Comme des Garçons builds niche perfume empire |publisher=International Herald Tribune |date=2013-09-17 |accessdate=2013-09-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081012073911/http://www.iht.com/articles/2007/10/15/style/FPERFUME.php |archivedate=October 12, 2008 }} The company released its first fragrance, ''Comme des Garçons'', in 1994.[http://hypebeast.com/2007/03/comme-des-garcons-perfume/ hypebeast: Comme des Garçons Perfume] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081015005835/http://hypebeast.com/2007/03/comme-des-garcons-perfume/ |date=October 15, 2008 }} 1998 saw the release of Comme des Garçons's first "anti-perfume" ''Odeur 53'',{{cite web|url=http://www.wallpaper.com/beauty/new-comme-des-garcons-perfume/2338 |title=New Comme des Garçons perfume |publisher=Wallpaper |date=2008-05-09 |accessdate=2013-09-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090208142420/http://www.wallpaper.com/beauty/new-comme-des-garcons-perfume/2338 |archivedate=2009-02-08 |df= }} a blend of 53 non-traditional notes to create a modern and striking scent.{{cite web|url=http://theconveyorbelt.com/index.php/archives/234 |title=Comme des Garçons |publisher=The Conveyor Belt |date=2008-03-20 |accessdate=2013-09-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130927215840/http://theconveyorbelt.com/index.php/archives/234 |archivedate=2013-09-27 |df= }} Some of these notes are: oxygen, flash of metal, wash drying in the wind, mineral carbon, sand dunes, nail polish, cellulose, pure air of the high mountains, burnt rubber, and flaming rock. Director [[John Waters]] and architect [[Roman and Williams|Stephen Alesch]] both wear the fragrance.{{cite news|newspaper=Artforum International|date=October 1, 1998|title=John Waters' top ten.}}{{cite web|url=https://www.gq.com/style/blogs/the-gq-eye/2010/01/qa-stephen-alesch-of-roman-and-williams.html|title=Style Secrets of NYC's Most In-Demand Designer|last=Chen|first=Jason|date=January 28, 2010|accessdate=June 29, 2014}} Comme des Garçons released the perfume for the Luxe series "Champaca", for which artist [[Katerina Jebb]] produced the visuals. Since 2002, the perfume line joined [[Puig (company)|Puig]] company to become part of its catalogue of fragrances.{{cite web |url=http://www.hola.com/belleza/actualidad/2002091647764/belleza/actualidad/noticiacommegarconspuig/ | title = Comme des Garcons, new signing Puig | accessdate = 29 April 2012 | publisher = ¡Hola!}} The company [[Puig (company)|Puig]] owns a partial license for Comme des Garçons fragrances under company of, Comme des Garçons Parfums.{{Cite web|url=https://next.ft.com/content/4ce0c520-7d35-11e3-a579-00144feabdc0|title=Lunch with the FT: Adrian Joffe - FT.com|access-date=2016-08-03}} Since granting a partial license for fragrances to [[Puig (company)|Puig]], Joffe has also created a division of fragrances within the Comme des Garçons company itself named, Comme des Garçons Parfums Parfums.{{Cite news|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/2/4ce0c520-7d35-11e3-a579-00144feabdc0.html?siteedition=intl|title=Lunch with the FT: Adrian Joffe|last=Friedman|first=Vanessa|newspaper=Financial Times|issn=0307-1766|access-date=2016-08-03}} Comme des Garçons developed a unisex fragrance, G I R L, with [[Pharrell Williams]], released on 28 August 2014.{{cite web|website=Dover Street Market New York |accessdate=22 August 2014 |url=http://shop.doverstreetmarket.com/us/comme-des-garcons/parfums-1/g-i-r-l-by-pharrell-williams-eau-de-parfum-100ml-natural-spray |title=G I R L by Pharrell Williams Eau de Parfum (100ml natural spray) |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140826114200/http://shop.doverstreetmarket.com/us/comme-des-garcons/parfums-1/g-i-r-l-by-pharrell-williams-eau-de-parfum-100ml-natural-spray |archivedate=26 August 2014 |df= }} Artist [[KAWS (artist)|KAWS]] designed the bottle.{{cite web|url=http://www.vogue.co.uk/beauty/2014/03/12/pharrell-williams-comme-des-garcons-fragrance-collaboration-girl |title= The Scent of Pharrell | last=Kilcooley-O'Halloran|first=Scarlett|date=March 12, 2014|accessdate=March 12, 2014}} ==Stores== [[Image:CdG.JPG|thumb|Aoyama Store]] Signature Comme des Garçons boutiques are located in [[London]] ([[Dover Street Market]]), [[Paris]], [[New York City]],[http://www.future-systems.com/architecture/architecture_12.html# Future Systems: Comme des Garçonss] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080415150321/http://www.future-systems.com/architecture/architecture_12.html%23 |date=April 15, 2008 }} [[Beijing]],[http://www.highsnobiety.com/home/the_daily_news/archive/2008/may/02/comme_des_garcons_beijing_flagship_store/index.htm highsnobiety: Comme des Garçons Beijing flagship store] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080503100434/http://www.highsnobiety.com/home/the_daily_news/archive/2008/may/02/comme_des_garcons_beijing_flagship_store/index.htm |date=May 3, 2008 }} [[Hong Kong]],[http://hypebeast.com/2007/04/comme-des-garcons-store-2007-hong-kong/ highsnobiety: Comme des Garçons Store 2007 Hong Kong] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080517050535/http://hypebeast.com/2007/04/comme-des-garcons-store-2007-hong-kong/ |date=May 17, 2008 }} [[Seoul]], [[St. Petersburg]], [[Tokyo]] (2x), [[Kyoto]], [[Osaka]], [[Fukuoka, Fukuoka|Fukuoka]]. The company also maintains [[Concession (contract)|concessions]] at select [[department stores]], such as [[Isetan]]. In [[Paris]], a Comme des Garçons perfumery can be found at 23 Place Marché St-Honoré. Comme des Garçons opened the first of their '[[Guerrilla]]' stores in 2004 in [[Berlin]].{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/12/12/magazine/12ANTI.html?_r=1&oref=slogin |title=The New York Times: The Anti-Concept Concept Store |publisher=Nytimes.com |date= 2004-12-12|accessdate=2013-09-24 |first=Amanda |last=Fortini}} The aim of the Guerrilla stores is to be open for only one year{{cite news|author=Cathy Horyn|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/02/17/nyregion/a-store-made-for-right-now-you-shop-until-it-s-dropped.html |title=The New York Times: A Store Made for Right Now: You Shop Until It's Dropped |publisher=New York Times |date=2004-02-17 |accessdate=2013-09-24}} and to spend a minimal amount of money on the interiors.{{cite web|url=http://archimedespool.wordpress.com/2007/09/21/guerrilla-store/ |title=Archimedes Pool: Guerrilla Store by Comme des Garçons |publisher=Archimedespool.wordpress.com |date=2007-09-21 |accessdate=2013-09-24}} The stores also are to be located away from fashionable hubs and districts of a city. Comme des Garçons Guerrilla stores have been opened (and subsequently closed) in Reykjavik, Warsaw, Helsinki, Singapore, Stockholm, and Athens, amongst others. In July 2007, a Guerrilla Store opened in the [[Achrafieh]] district of Beirut, Lebanon, and in February 2008, a Guerrilla Store opened in downtown Los Angeles, the first in the United States.{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2008/feb/17/image/ig-comme17 |title=Los Angeles Times: A hip hideaway |publisher=Articles.latimes.com |date=2008-02-17 |accessdate=2013-09-24 |first=Emili |last=Vesilind}} In November 2008, they opened another Guerilla store in the west end of [[Glasgow]]. 2004 also saw the opening in [[London]] of [[Dover Street Market]] (DSM),[https://web.archive.org/web/20081017174947/http://www.iconeye.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=2685%3Adover-street-market--icon-017--november-2004 icon eye: Dover Street Market]{{cite news|author=Tamsin Blanchard |url=http://observer.guardian.co.uk/magazine/story/0,11913,1316699,00.html |title=The Observer: Shabby chic |publisher=Observer.guardian.co.uk |date=2004-10-03 |accessdate=2013-09-24 |location=London}} a multilevel store conceptualised by [[Rei Kawakubo]]. In December 2009, Comme des Garçons opened a {{convert|4400|sqft|m2}} store in [[Hong Kong]] called ''Under The Ground''. Hong Kong also has had a Guerrilla store opened and closed in previous years, run by Silly Thing Hong Kong.[http://hypebeast.com/2007/03/comme-des-garcons-hong-kong-2/ hypebeast: Comme des Garçons Hong Kong] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080501114434/http://hypebeast.com/2007/03/comme-des-garcons-hong-kong-2/ |date=May 1, 2008 }} In March 2012, Comme des Garçons opened a store in One Rockwell, [[Rockwell Center]], [[Metro Manila|Manila]]. Also, the first Dover Street Market in Japan opened in Ginza.[http://www.doverstreetmarket.com/ginza/featured_brands.html Expected brands at DSM] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120124092653/http://www.doverstreetmarket.com/ginza/featured_brands.html |date=January 24, 2012 }} In December 2013, [[Dover Street Market]] in New York City opened.{{cite news|author=Jacob Bernstein |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/12/26/fashion/Dover-Street-Market-New-York-City.html |title=At Dover Street Market, Differences of Opinion |publisher=nytimes.com |date=2013-12-24 |accessdate=2014-01-30}} ==Museum exhibition in 2017== {{Main|Rei Kawakubo/Comme des Garçons Art of the In-Between}} Starting in May 2017, Rei Kawakubo will be the subject of one of the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]]'s fashion exhibitions in New York.Time magazine. Kawakubo announcement of 2017 exhibit. [http://time.com/4540904/comme-des-garcons-rei-kawakubo-met-gala-theme-2017/] ''Vogue'' magazine and the Metropolitan Museum in New York have announced that the exhibition dedicated to Kawakubo is scheduled for its 2017 season between 4 May 2017 and 4 September 2017. In an interview with ''Vogue'' in April 2017, [[Andrew Bolton (curator)|Andrew Bolton]], the curator for the Kawakubo exhibit at the Met stated: “I really think her influence is so huge, but sometimes it’s subtle. It’s not about copying her; it’s the purity of her vision... Rei was really involved in the design of the exhibit”.Lynn Yaeger. "On the Eve of the Comme des Garçons Retrospective, the Notoriously Reclusive Rei Kawakubo Speaks Out", APRIL 13, 2017, ''Vogue'' Magazine. Bolton also stated that the exhibit in May 2017 will be an austere, all-white maze hosting approximately 150 Comme ensembles. Both the exhibit and accompanying book by Bolton are based upon the recurrent fashion dichotomies concentrating on eight thematic oppositions listed as: (1) fashion/antifashion; (2) design/not design; (3) model/multiple; (4) then/now; (5) high/low; (6) self/other; (7) object/subject; and (8) clothes/not clothes. ==Rei Kawakubo quotations== *"For something to be beautiful...it doesn't have to be pretty." *"Fashion is something that you can attach to yourself, put on, and through that interaction, the meaning of it is born." *"I make clothes for a woman who is not swayed by what her husband thinks." *"Comme des Garcons is a gift to oneself, not something to appeal or to attract the opposite sex." *"The theme of the collection this time is MONSTER. It's not about the typical Monster you find in sci-fi and video games. The expression of the Monsters I have made has a much deeper meaning. The craziness of humanity, the fear we all have, the feeling of going beyond common sense, the absence of ordinariness, expressed by something extremely big, by something that could be ugly or beautiful. In other words, I wanted to question the established standards of beauty." *"My intention is not to make clothes. My head would be too restricted if I only thought about making clothes."http://www.azquotes.com/quote/617912 ==Comme des Garçons lines== ;Designed by [[Rei Kawakubo]] * Comme des Garçons – main womenswear line (since 1973) * Comme des Garçons Noir – black-dominated womenswear collection (since 1987) * Comme des Garçons Comme Des Garçons – (a.k.a. 'Comme Comme') womenswear (since 1993) * Comme des Garçons Homme Plus – main menswear line (since 1984) * Comme des Garçons Homme Plus Sport – sporty subline of Homme Plus * Comme des Garçons Homme Plus Evergreen – subline of Homme Plus, re-invented items from past collections (since 2005) * Comme des Garçons Homme Deux – formal tailored menswear (since 1987) * Comme des Garçons SHIRT – shirt-dominated collection (since 1988) * Comme des Garçons SHIRT Girl * Comme des Garçons SHIRT Boy (Since 2014) * Comme des Garçons Girl (Since 2015) * Play Comme des Garçons – casual streetwear for younger men and women with bug-eyed heart logo (collaboration with [[New York City]] graphic artist Filip Pagowski ) * BLACK Comme des Garçons – unisex, lower-priced line, initially started due to the recession in 2008. also sold in signature BLACK pop-up shops. ;Designed by [[Junya Watanabe]] * Comme des Garçons Homme – menswear Japanese line (since 1978) * Comme des Garçons Robe de Chambre – womenswear Japanese line (discontinued) * Junya Watanabe Comme des Garçons – womenswear (since 1992) * Junya Watanabe Comme des Garçons Man – menswear (since 2001) * Junya Watanabe Comme des Garçons Man Pink – menswear items for women (discontinued) ;Designed by Tao Kurihara * Tao Comme des Garçons – womenswear (launched 2005, discontinued after spring 2011) * Tricot Comme des Garçons – womenwear knits ;Designed by Fumito Ganryu * Ganryu Comme des Garçons – asexual street style label, Ganryu was a former pattern-maker at Junya ;Designed by Kei Ninomiya *Noir Kei Ninomiya - womenswear (launched in 2013), Ninomiya was a former pattern-maker at CdG ;Accessories * Comme des Garçons Edited – special items for Edited shops in Japan * Comme des Garçons Pearl – jewelry (since 2006) * Comme des Garçons Parfum – (since 1994) * Comme des Garçons Parfum Parfum * Comme des Garçons Wallet * Speedo Comme des Garçons – swimwear collaboration (since 2005) * Hammerthor Comme des Garçons Shirt – underwear collaboration (since 2007) ;Others * Comme des Garçons Peggy Moffitt * Comme des Garçons Six – bi-annual magazine (from 1988 to 1991) ;Collaborations * design collaborations with mainstream brands – e.g. [[J.Crew]], [[Levi's]], [[Lacoste]], [[Fred Perry]], [[The North Face]], [[Supreme (brand)|Supreme]], [[Nike, Inc.]], ''[[Monocle (media company)|Monocle]]'', [[H&M]], [[Jun Takahashi|Undercover]], [[Visvim]], [[Chrome Hearts]], 10.Corso.Como, Kaws, [[Louis Vuitton]], etc. ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{toomanylinks|date=January 2018}} *[http://www.comme-des-garcons.com/ Official '''Comme des Garçons''' company website] *[http://comme-des-garcons-parfum.com/ Official Comme des Garçons Parfums website] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Comme Des Garcons}} [[Category:Clothing brands of Japan]] [[Category:Clothing companies of Japan]] [[Category:High fashion brands]] [[Category:Luxury brands]] [[Category:Perfume houses]] [[Category:Retail companies based in Tokyo]] [[Category:Clothing companies established in 1973]] [[Category:Retail companies established in 1973]] [[Category:1973 establishments in Japan]] [[Category:Japanese brands]]

revision.comment: corrected diagram at top of page as being an Euler diagram rather than a Venn diagram
modification based on new research. Source added
revision.text:
{{Anti-consumerism |Theories}}
'''Consumer capitalism''' is a theoretical economic and social political condition in which [[demand|consumer demand]] is manipulated, in a deliberate and coordinated way, on a very large scale, through [[mass-marketing]] techniques, to the advantage of sellers.
This theory is controversial. It suggests manipulation of consumer demand so potent that it has a [[coercion|coercive]] effect, amounts to a departure from [[free-market capitalism]], and has an adverse effect on society in general. According to one source, the power of such 'manipulation' is not straightforward. It depends upon a new kind of individualism - ''projective individualism'', where persons use consumer capitalism to project the kind of person who they want to be.<ref>{{Cite journal | year=2012 | last1= James | first1= Paul | last2= Scerri | first2= Andy | authorlink1= Paul James (academic) | title= Globalizing Consumption and the Deferral of a Politics of Consequence | url= https://www.academia.edu/3230921/Globalizing_Consumption_and_the_Deferral_of_a_Politics_of_Consequence | journal= Globalizations | volume= 9 | issue= 2 | pages= 225–240}}</ref>
Some use the phrase as shorthand for the broader idea that the interests of other non-business entities (governments, religions, the military, educational institutions) are intertwined with corporate business interests, and that those entities also participate in the management of social expectations through mass media.
== Origins ==
The origins of consumer capitalism<ref>{{cite book|last=Silla|first=Cesare|title=The Rise of Consumer Capitalism in America, 1880-1930|year=2018|publisher=Routledge|location=London-New York|url= https://books.google.it/books?id=oqVYDwAAQBAJ&pg=PT1&lpg=PT1&dq=the+rise+of+consumer+capitalism+in+america&source=bl&ots=ZbDa8RGHMV&sig=QfS3VAuSNLwfU2eXMH2wi4pKB2U&hl=it&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjf2cWsw_3aAhUrKpoKHTzvDRcQ6AEIUDAF#v=onepage&q=the%20rise%20of%20consumer%20capitalism%20in%20america&f=false}}</ref> are found in the development of American [[department store]]s from the mid 19th Century, notably the advertising and marketing innovations at [[Wanamaker's]] in [[Philadelphia]]<ref>{{cite book|last=Leach|first=William|title=Land of Desire|year=1993|publisher=Pantheon Books|location=New York|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VHZ6UAudSiUC&pg=330}}</ref>. Author William Leach describes a deliberate, coordinated effort among American '[[Captain of industry|captains of industry]]' to detach consumer demand from 'needs' (which can be satisfied) to 'wants' (which may remain unsatisfied). This cultural shift represented by the department store is also explored in [[Émile Zola]]'s 1883 novel ''[[Au Bonheur des Dames]]'', which describes the workings and the appeal of a fictionalized version of [[Le Bon Marché]].
In 1919 [[Edward Bernays]] began his career as the 'father of [[public relations]]' and successfully applied the developing principles of psychology, sociology and motivational research to manipulate public opinion in favor of products like cigarettes, soap, and [[Calvin Coolidge]]. New techniques of mechanical reproduction developed in these decades improved the channels of mass-market communication and its manipulative power. This development was described as early as the 1920s by [[Walter Benjamin]] and related members of the [[Frankfurt School]], who foresaw the commercial, societal and political implications.
In business history, the mid-1920s saw [[Alfred P. Sloan]] stimulating increased demand for [[General Motors]] products by instituting the annual model year change and [[planned obsolescence]], a move that changed the dynamics of the largest industrial enterprise in the world, away from technological innovation and towards satisfying market expectations.
Probably the most obvious example of consumer capital tactics in the United States' history occurred during the first world war. During which the United States' government put out several campaigns and advertisements aimed to gain support for engaging in the war. At this time the government's involvement in the economy was known as propaganda. Advertisements, posters and campaigns were found everywhere, encouraging the public to add to the economy and consume more. Many of these public attempts encouraged mass consumption of domestic food to help put back into the economy and support the war. and In her book, Celia Malone Kingsbury even discusses how during the war the government manipulated the economy in such a way that the consumption of domestic food was made into a "powerful weapon."<ref>Kingsbury, Celia Malone. For Home and Country: World War I Propaganda on the Home Front. Lincoln: University of Nebraska, 2010. Print. </ref> The government manipulated the public by turning commercialism into a sort of nationalism, pride and support of one's country.
== Criticism == An important contribution to the critique of consumer capitalism has been made by the French philosopher [[Bernard Stiegler]], but very little of this has been translated into English. Stiegler argues that capitalism today is governed not by production but by consumption, and that the techniques used to create consumer behavior amount to the destruction of psychic and collective [[individuation]]. The diversion of libidinal energy toward the consumption of consumer products, he argues, results in an addictive cycle, leading to hyperconsumption, the exhaustion of desire, and the reign of symbolic misery.<ref>Stiegler discusses consumer capitalism in his article [http://www.arsindustrialis.org/disaffected-individual-process-psychic-and-collective-disindividuation The Disaffected Individual]. His response to the situation can be discerned by reading the [http://www.arsindustrialis.org/manifeste/index_html-en?set_language=en&cl=en manifesto] of his political group, [http://www.arsindustrialis.org/ Ars Industrialis].</ref>
==Consumer capitalism today==
In light of the economic hardships the United States is today experiencing as a result of radical wealth inequalities, and perhaps a strong dependence on oil, consumer capitalist tactics have turned to credit as a means to maintaining a high level of expenditures in the form of consumer demand. Some of these tactics, to cite one extremely peripheral example, include government incentives to buy eco-friendly 'green' products, such as tax deductions for energy conserving home improvements or the purchasing of hybrid cars. These tactics, however, are not without critics. James Gustave Speth, former dean of the Yale School of Forestry and Environmental Studies, and author of ''The Bridge at the Edge of the World: Capitalism, the Environment, and Crossing from Crisis to Sustainability,'' does not believe the United States government should implement such tactics. Instead Gustave believes in more direct approaches to repair or avoid environmental damage. Rather than focusing on re-boosting the distressed economy, treat the problem.<ref>Speth, James G. The Bridge at the Edge of the World: Capitalism, the Environment, and Crossing from Crisis to Sustainability. Yale School of Forestry & Environmental Studies - Masters of Environmental Management. Web. 27 Feb. 2011. < http://environment.yale.edu/news/5647/ >. </ref>

'''Contentious politics''' is the use of disruptive techniques to make a [[politics|political]] point, or to change government policy. Examples of such techniques are actions that disturb the normal activities of society such as [[Demonstration (people)|demonstrations]], general [[strike action]], [[riot]], [[terrorism]], [[civil disobedience]], and even [[revolution]] or [[insurrection]]. [[Social movements]] often engage in contentious politics. The concept distinguishes these forms of contention from the everyday acts of resistance explored by [[James C. Scott]], interstate warfare, and forms of contention employed entirely within institutional settings, such as elections or sports. Historical sociologist [[Charles Tilly]] defines contentious politics as "interactions in which actors make claims bearing on someone else's interest, in which governments appear either as targets, initiators of claims, or third parties."<ref>Tilly, Charles. Contentious Performances. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2008: 5.</ref>
Contentious politics has existed forever, but its form varies over time and space. For example, Tilly argues that the nature of contentious politics changed fairly dramatically with the birth of [[social movements]] in 18th-century Europe.
The concept of contentious politics was developed throughout the 1990s and into the 21st century by its most prominent scholars in the United States: [[Sidney Tarrow]], Charles Tilly, and [[Doug McAdam]]. Until its development, the study of contentious politics was divided among a number of traditions each of which were concerned with the description and explanation of different contentious political phenomena, especially the social movement, the strike, and revolution. One of the primary goals of these three authors was to advance the explanation of these phenomena and other contentious politics under a single research agenda.<ref>McAdam, Doug, Sidney Tarrow, and Charles Tilly. Dynamics of Contention. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2001.</ref> There remains a significant plurality of agendas in addition to the one these three propose.
