revision.text:
[[File:AP - Peripheral Vision.pdf|thumb|Peripheral vision of the human eye.]]
'''Vision span''' or '''perceptual span''' is a controversial concept referring to the angular span (vertically and horizontally), within which the [[human eye]] has sharp enough [[Visual perception|vision]] to perform an action accurately (reading or face recognition). The [[visual field]] of the human eye spans approximately 120 [[Degree (angle)|degrees of arc]]. However, most of that arc is [[peripheral vision]]. The human eye has much greater [[Optical resolution|resolution]] in the [[macula]], where there is a higher density of [[cone cell]]s. The [[field of view]] that is observed with sufficient resolution to read text typically spans about 6 degrees of arc, which is wide enough to allow a clear view of about five words in a row when printed text at ordinary size is held about 50 centimeters from the eyes. Regarding face processing, the [[field of view]] with a sufficient amount of information in order to recognise faces accurately spans about 7° which represents about 45% of a face.<ref name=FS>{{cite journal |doi=10.1167/17.5.16 |pmid=28549354 |title=The Facespan—the perceptual span for face recognition |journal=Journal of Vision |volume=17 |issue=5 |pages=16 |year=2017 |last1=Papinutto |first1=Michael |last2=Lao |first2=Junpeng |last3=Ramon |first3=Meike |last4=Caldara |first4=Roberto |last5=Miellet |first5=Sébastien }}</ref> The brain creates the illusion of having a greater visual span by automatically and unconsciously moving the center of vision into any area of interest in the field of view.
==Application to speed reading==
While reading, readers will fail to recognize a word unless they are fixating within three to four character spaces of the word.<ref name=Rayner1975>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/0010-0285(75)90005-5 |title=The perceptual span and peripheral cues in reading |journal=Cognitive Psychology |volume=7 |issue=4 |pages=65–81 |year=1975 |last1=Rayner |first1=Keith |bibcode=1992CogPs..24..535V }}</ref> The same is true for [[speed reading|speed readers]] and [[Skimming (reading)|skimmers]]. Speed readers cannot answer questions about a main point or detail, if they did not fixate directly on it or within three character spaces of it (Just and Carpenter 1987). When a text is removed whilst reading, readers can only accurately report upon the word they were fixating upon or the next one to the right (McConkie and Hogaoam 1985). There is no evidence from eye movement research that individuals are making predictions of text based upon hypotheses about the words in the periphery so that they can skip over or spend less time on unimportant or redundant words.<ref name=Rayner1975/>
Most speed reading courses claim that the peripheral vision can be used to read text. This has been suggested impossible because the text is blurred out through lack of visual resolution. At best the human brain can only ''guess'' at the content of text outside the macular region. There simply are not enough cone cells away from the center of the visual field to identify words in the periphery of the field.
It has been suggested that the fixation span can be stretched through training ([[meta guiding]]) to take in as much as a line for the purpose of skimming or speed reading.<ref>{{Cite journal|pmc = 2729064|year = 2007|last1 = Legge|first1 = G. E|title = The case for the visual span as a sensory bottleneck in reading|journal = Journal of Vision|volume = 7|issue = 2|pages = 9.1–915|last2 = Cheung|first2 = S. H|last3 = Yu|first3 = D|last4 = Chung|first4 = S. T|last5 = Lee|first5 = H. W|last6 = Owens|first6 = D. P|pmid = 18217824|doi = 10.1167/7.2.9}}</ref> However other sources suggest that using this method can result in a severely reduced comprehension rate in comparison to normal reading ("[[rauding]]").
Some speed reading courses stress that the human eye has to move very quickly. They also stress that the human eye should move in a pattern to fill in the information that was not properly perceived. The effective limit for [[wikt:scan|scan]]ning speeds based upon the limit of the human eye's resolution is about 300 words per minute.<ref>http://skepdic.com/speedreading.html{{full citation needed|date=August 2018}}</ref> It is claimed that such speeds also require great practice, and extremely rapid eye movements, although research suggests that such training is not possible. It has been suggested by some speed reading promoters that the readers who achieve such speeds are on the [[autism spectrum]]. Research into reading rate suggests that study strategies, rather than speed reading, explains why expert readers, such as professors and editors, are more efficient than others.
==Application to face processing==
Face recognition system requires several fixation on different location (typically in a triangular pattern) for a face to be recognised. The same is true for the so-called Super Recognisers who are persons with high face recognition capabilities. Similarly to the reading span, the Facespan might be modulated by difficulty,<ref>http://psycnet.apa.org/buy/1990-18858-001{{full citation needed|date=August 2018}}</ref> expertise,<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.3758/PBR.17.6.834 |pmid=21169577 |title=Eye movements, the perceptual span, and reading speed |journal=Psychonomic Bulletin & Review |volume=17 |issue=6 |pages=834 |year=2010 |last1=Rayner |first1=Keith |last2=Slattery |first2=Timothy J |last3=Bélanger |first3=Nathalie N |pmc=3075059 }}</ref> age,<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/0022-0965(86)90037-8 |pmid=3701249 |title=Eye movements and the perceptual span in beginning and skilled readers |journal=Journal of Experimental Child Psychology |volume=41 |issue=2 |pages=211–36 |year=1986 |last1=Rayner |first1=Keith }}</ref> disorder <ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1007/BF02648003 |title=Eye movements, perceptual span, and reading disability |journal=Annals of Dyslexia |volume=33 |pages=163–173 |year=1983 |last1=Rayner |first1=Keith }}</ref> and other idiosyncratic differences between individuals. The idiosyncratic differences are thus most probably due to differences in Facespan rather than in oculomotor strategy. Previous study revealed that the Vision span is more accurately defined in number of characters rather than in visual angle.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1111/j.1467-9280.2009.02364.x |pmid=19470124 |title=Parafoveal Magnification |journal=Psychological Science |volume=20 |issue=6 |pages=721–8 |year=2009 |last1=Miellet |first1=Sébastien |last2=O'Donnell |first2=Patrick J |last3=Sereno |first3=Sara C }}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== {{More footnotes|article|date=April 2018}} *McConkie and Hogaoam 1985. Eye position and word identification during reading. In R. Groner et al.'s ''Eye movements and information processing''. Amsterdam, Elsevier. *Just and Carpenter 1987 In Allyn & Bacon's ''The Psychology of Reading and Language Comprehension''. Boston.
== See also == * [[PhotoReading]]
[[Category:Vision]] [[Category:Reading (process)]] [[Category:Educational psychology]]

{{about|tour of a historical, or cultural or artistic site|tours involving walks in the country|Hiking}} [[File:Tourists with guide in lower canyon, Petra.jpg|thumb|Tourists on a walking tour of the lower canyon at [[Petra]], Jordan]] A '''walking tour''' is a tour of a historical or cultural site undertaken on foot, frequently in an urban setting.<ref>http://oxforddictionaries.com/view/entry/m_en_us1304940#m_en_us1304940 Oxford Dictionary 1</ref> Short tours can last under an hour, while longer ones can take in multiple sits and last a full day or more. A walk can be led by a [[tour guide]], as an escort.
==Precursors== A [[Grand Tour]] was "a long tour of major cities" undertaken in Europe in the 17th through 19th centuries, as part of a wealthy young man's education,<ref>''The Canadian Oxford Dictionary'' (1998), and ''New Oxford American Dictionary''.</ref> and involved visits to cities, historic and cultural sites, with pedestrian activity confined to these cities or sites.
A [[pilgrimage]] is a religious journey traditionally taken on foot, to a location of significance to the walker's faith. Only a minority of contemporary pilgrimages are on foot. Chaucer's 14th-century narrative poem ''[[Canterbury Tales]]'' certainly indicates that a pilgrimage can involve pleasure.
There are also similarities between walking tours that involve long hikes and [[backpacking (wilderness)|backpacking]], while [[backpacking (travel)|non-pedestrian backpacking]] is a kind of modern, inexpensive Grand Tour that makes use of [[public transport]].
==Tours of cities and cultural sites== [[File:Free Walking Tour in Baden-Baden.jpg|thumb|A walking tour in Baden-Baden]] [[File:YorkPavementButton1.jpg|thumb|A glass stud in [[York]] sidewalk. Such glass studs are the remnants of the York Breadcrumbs trail, an initiative from 2005 which incorporated three custom walking tours and (now defunct) website. The tours included the Minster, the Shambles, the Guildhall etc. with a story thrown in.]] ===With guides=== A walking tour is generally distinguished from an [[escorted tour]] by its length and the employment of [[tour guides]], and can be under 12 hours, or last for a week or more. They are led by guides that have knowledge of the sites, or the landscape, covered on the tour, and explanations and interpretations of the site can cover a range of subjects, including places with historical, cultural and artistic significance. Walking tours, of various kinds and length, are universally part of the tourism industry, and can be found around the world.
Many walking tours involve a payment to the guide, although some operate on a [[Gratuity|tip]] system.<ref>{{cite news | first = Agnes | last = Molnar | title = Strassenökonom – die Stadtführerin | url = http://www.capital.de/dasmagazin/strassenoekonom-die-stadtfuehrerin.html | work = Capital | publisher = G+J Wirtschaftsmedien GmbH & Co. KG | date = 2014-04-25 | accessdate = 2016-01-25 | language = de }}</ref> The "pay what you want" model started around 2004, and can be found in many countries. The UK-based Guild of Registered Tour has criticised the system for not requiring any training or certification of its guides.<ref>{{cite news | first = Vicky | last = Baker | title = The rise of the 'free' city tour | url = https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2013/jun/12/free-pay-you-want-city-tours | work = the Guardian | date = 2013-06-12 | accessdate = 2016-01-25 | language = en }}</ref>
===Narratives=== Several cities now have groups that are employing dramatic spectacle to add interest to their tours. Usually guided by actors in costume playing a role, these walking tours create the feel of [[living history]] as guests walk in the footsteps of those who came before them. These tours, which blend history and dramatic narrative, share "history in a non-academic, very accessible fashion."<ref>{{cite web|last1=Handley|first1=Gen|title=Forbidden Vancouver tour reenacts Gastown's gothic adventures|url=http://www.westender.com/news/forbidden-vancouver-tour-reenacts-gastown-s-gothic-adventures-1.882003|website=The Westender|publisher=The Westender|accessdate=11 June 2015}}</ref>
These tours are similar in nature to [[promenade theatre]]. Although the theatrical nature of these tours is similar to [[museum theatre]] in that it makes use of [[Museum theatre#First-person interpretation|first person interpretation]], the fact that these tours take place outside of traditional museum settings and requires the audience to move through urban environments makes this style of walking tour a genre of its own.
===Self guided tours=== [[Self-guided tour|Self-guided]] tours, utilise a range of methods to aid travel through a place, or landscape, such as books,<ref>{{Citation | title=Frommer's walking tours. Paris | publication-date=1993 | publisher=Prentice Hall Travel | issn=1081-3381 }}</ref><ref>{{Citation | author1=Legarde, Lisa | title=Frommer's walking tours. San Francisco | publication-date=1993 | publisher=Prentice Hall Travel | issn=1081-3403 }}</ref> maps, pamphlets, and audio material.<ref>{{Citation | author1=Wooldridge, Denyse. (Narrator) | author2=Dee's Audio Walking Tours | title=Manhattan Midtown West | publication-date=1996 | publisher=Dee's Audio Walking Tours | url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/work/34227764 | accessdate=19 April 2013 }}</ref>
===Day tours with specific locations=== *[[Boston By Foot]] ([[Boston]], USA) *[[Big Onion Walking Tours]] ([[New York City]]) *[[Photowalking]] *[[Caminhada Noturna]], [[São Paulo]]
==See also== *[[Audio tour]] *[[Backpacking (wilderness)]] *[[Backpacking (travel)]] *[[Campustours]] *[[Free Walking Tour]] *[[Heritage trail]] *[[Hiking]]
== References == {{reflist}}
==Further reading== * MacCannell, Dean. ''The Ethics of Sightseeing''. University of California Press, 2011. * Pond, Kathleen Lingle. ''The Professional Guide: Dynamics of Tour Guiding''. New York: Van Nostrand Reinhold, 1993. * Ruitenberg, Claudia W. "Learning by Walking: Non-Formal Education as Curatorial Practice and Intervention in Public Space." ''International Journal of Lifelong Education'' 31, no. 3 (2012): 261-275. * Wynn, Jonathan R. ''The Tour Guide: Walking and Talking New York''. Chicago: The University of Chicago Press, 2011. * Wynn, Jonathan R. "City Tour Guides: Urban Alchemists at Work." ''City & Community'' 9, no. 2 (June 2010).

{{Other uses}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2012}} {{Use Jamaican English|date=March 2012}} {{Infobox Criminal organization | name = Yardies | image = | caption = | founded = | founding location = [[Jamaica]] | founded by = | years active = 1950s–present | territory = Jamaica, [[United Kingdom]], [[United States]], [[Canada]] | ethnic makeup = [[Jamaicans|Jamaican]], [[British Jamaican]], [[Jamaican-American]], [[Jamaican-Canadian]] | membership est = | criminal activities = [[Drug-trafficking]], [[political corruption]], [[Assassination]] | allies = | rivals= }}
'''Yardie''' (or '''Yaadi''') is a term often used, particularly within the [[Caribbean]] expatriate and [[Jamaican diaspora]] community, to refer to persons of [[Jamaica]]n origin, though its exact meaning changes depending on context. The term is derived from the [[Jamaican patois]] for home or "yard".<ref>{{Cite book|title = New Register of Caribbean English Usage|last = Allsop|first = Richard|publisher = University of the West Indies Press|year = 2010|isbn = 978-976-640-298-3|location = Jamaica|pages = }}</ref> The term may have specifically originated from the crowded [[Trenchtown|government yards]] of two-storey concrete homes found in [[Kingston, Jamaica|Kingston]] and inhabited by poorer Jamaican residents.<ref name="covey">{{cite book|last1=Covey|first1=Herbert|title=Street Gangs Throughout the World|date=2010|location=Springfirld, Illinois|publisher=Charles C Thomas Publisher|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RlZ3CAAAQBAJ&pg=PA148&lpg=PA148&dq=government+yard+yardies&source=bl&ots=GYpj9NIDBd&sig=IufbMf5wtZop8mv_zHvnGlC4UyA&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj_kpWbzZTQAhVK4IMKHYaZAdgQ6AEIRDAI#v=onepage&q=government%20yard%20yardies&f=false}}</ref>
However, especially outside of Jamaica, "yardies" or "the Yardies" usually specifically refers to Jamaican [[gang]]s or [[organized crime]] groups and gangsters of Jamaican origin, nationality, or ethnicity. The term is often used interchangeably with the term "posse" or "[[Jamaican posse]]" to refer to crime groups of Jamaican origin, with the term "Posse" used more frequently in Jamaica, the [[United States]], and [[Canada]] to refer to Jamaican, [[Jamaican-American]], and [[Jamaican-Canadian]] crime groups, and "Yardies" being deployed more frequently in the [[United Kingdom]].<ref name="mccarthy">{{cite book|last1=McCarthy|first1=Dennis M. P.|title=An Economic History of Organized Crime: A National and Transnational Approach|date=2011|publisher=Routledge|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=s2KrAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA174&lpg=PA174&dq=jamaican+posses+yardies&source=bl&ots=3DhlnmHZSb&sig=pwqkBk8PDIjaY1npld6zccwKOrA&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwix7Njcy5TQAhWEyoMKHcSmCNg4ChDoAQgmMAM#v=onepage&q=jamaican%20posses%20yardies&f=false}}</ref> Yardie gangs or "posses" are involved in a wide array of criminal activity depending on their location, ranging from [[political corruption]], [[political violence]], and [[assassination]] in Jamaica to [[drug trafficking]] and [[gang violence]] in the U.S., Canada, and U.K.<ref name="covey"/><ref name="figueira">{{cite book|last1=Figueira|first1=Daurius|title=Cocaine and Heroin Trafficking in the Caribbean: The Case of Trinidad and Tobago, Jamaica and Guyana|date=2004|publisher=iUniverse|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mYKfc-tqhwEC&pg=PA21&lpg=PA21&dq=yardie+posses&source=bl&ots=cVxd6ygm6B&sig=yPcAS3NqrcW4EWzFPdrDB9hAVrw&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj8zN-iyZTQAhVo2oMKHaa2CkcQ6AEIaDAO#v=onepage&q=yardie%20posses&f=false}}</ref>
== Etymology and usage == Derived from [[Jamaican Patois]], the term "yardie" can be ambiguous, having multiple meanings depending on context.<ref name="mccarthy"/> In the most innocuous sense, "yardie" can simply refer to a Jamaican national; as "yard" can mean "home" in Jamaican Patois, Jamaican expatriates who moved abroad to countries such as the U.K. and U.S. would often refer to themselves and other Jamaicans as "yardies".<ref name="mccarthy"/> "Yardie" may also more specifically apply to those Jamaicans originating in the impoverished "government yards" or courtyards of Jamaican [[public housing]], and the term was eventually applied to criminals and gang members originating from these "yards."<ref name="covey"/><ref name="bbc">{{cite news|title=Who are the Yardies?|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/371604.stm|accessdate=6 November 2016|agency=BBC News|date=June 19, 1999}}</ref> As the term "yard" in Jamaican Patois can also refer to a territory, turf, or piece of land, "yardie" further gained gang or criminal connotations as Jamaican gangs or criminals claimed certain "territories" or "turf" and referred to such territory as their "yards."<ref name="mccarthy"/> Subsequently, in the U.K. and, to a lesser extent, [[North America]], the term "Yardie" most frequently refers to gangsters or gangs of Jamaica origin, though these gang members themselves may refer to their gangs as "posses" or "crews."<ref name="mccarthy"/><ref name="Wright2013"/> The term is especially common in the U.K. to describe Jamaican or [[British Jamaican]] organized crime groups and gangs, while "posse" has become the more common term in North America.<ref name="covey"/><ref name="mccarthy"/>
==Origins of "Yardie" organized crime groups== In the 1950s in [[Trenchtown]], [[Kingston, Jamaica]], the government created [[social housing]] developments employing large public courtyards, and the courtyard areas soon became the hub of social and recreational activity in the crowded housing of Trenchtown. With increasing overcrowding and poverty, however, [[squatting]] and [[homelessness]] developed within the yards. Crime, drug abuse, and violence overran the yards, while political corruption and [[clientelism]] led to local politicians buying and selling patronage within the community and paying gangs and violent political supporters to intimidate voters and threaten, assault, or kill political opponents.<ref name="gibson">{{cite book|last1=Gibson|first1=Carrie|title=Empire's Crossroads: The Caribbean From Columbus to the Present Day|date=2014|publisher=Pan Macmillan|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kXTAAwAAQBAJ&pg=PT275&dq=government+yards&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjYqbLIz5TQAhVKxoMKHaxZDvwQ6AEIGzAA#v=onepage&q=government%20yards&f=false}}</ref>
By the 1970s and 1980s, political violence and politically-affiliated organized crime groups and street gangs became increasingly common in poorer areas of Jamaica, with gangs often led by older bosses known as "[[don (honorific)|dons]]" (in reference to the [[Sicilian Mafia]] don) and participating in both apolitical drug trafficking and racketeering and political violence and political intimidation.<ref name="covey"/> These gangs became known as "Yardies," "posses", or "crews".<ref name="Wright2013"/> Accounts of the association between Jamaican political factions and the rise of the Yardies are given in the factual books [https://books.google.co.uk/books/about/Ruthless.html?id=18TrGwAACAAJ ''Ruthless''] by Geoff Small and ''[https://www.publishersweekly.com/978-0-8050-3205-5 Born Fi' Dead]'' by Laurie Gunst.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/books/extreme-prejudice-1528024.html|title=Extreme prejudice|last=Hobson|first=Will|date=31 December 1995|work=The Independent|access-date=25 June 2018}}</ref>
By the 1980s, a drop in government budgets resulted in less money being paid by political parties to their gangs of armed supporters. These political Yardie gangs thus increasingly turned to apolitical criminal activity, such as drug trafficking, to bring in income.<ref name="covey"/> At the same time, the Jamaican government severely cracked down on Yardie gangs and political violence in general, leading many so-called Yardie gangsters to immigrate abroad and establish gangs the U.K., U.S., and Canada.<ref name="abadinsky">{{cite book|last1=Abadinsky|first1=Howard|title=Organized Crime|date=2012|publisher=Cengage Learning|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HcoKAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA187&dq=yardies+jamaican+yard+criminals&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwji8pK14JTQAhXH7IMKHcZ7AqkQ6AEIGzAA#v=onepage&q=yardies%20jamaican%20yard%20criminals&f=false}}</ref> The establishment of Yardie gangs abroad coincided with the [[crack epidemic|rise of crack cocaine]] in both North America and the U.K., and Yardie and Posse gangs from Jamaica became heavily involved in the trafficking of [[crack cocaine]] and other drugs, in addition to [[illegal gambling]] and other criminal activity.<ref name="abadinsky"/>
== United Kingdom == During the 1950s, the British government encouraged immigration to the country to fill existing job vacancies. Within the [[Caribbean]] community, new arrivals from [[Jamaica]] were sometimes referred to as "Yardies" due to reference of Jamaica as "back a yard" (or "back home"). A large influx of inner city Jamaican immigration to Britain during the 1980s led to the rise of gang violence or behaviour on the part of Jamaicans which became known in wider [[British society]] as "Yardie culture" and the participants "Yardies". The terms "Yardie gang" or "Yardie gun violence" were largely used by the British media to describe violent crimes in [[London]]'s [[Black British|black community]]. The gangs in London are specifically known to have occupied and operated in their infamous grounds of [[Brixton]], [[Harlesden]], [[Hackney Central|Hackney]], [[Tottenham]], [[Peckham]] and [[Notting Hill]].<ref name="Wright2013">{{cite book|author=Alan Wright|title=Organised Crime|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7LWDR0BuafAC&pg=PT211|date=17 June 2013|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-134-01890-1|pages=211–}}</ref>
Jamaican-born British writer [[Victor Headley]] wrote a bestselling 1992 novel entitled ''[[Yardie (novel)|Yardie]]''. In 2018, British actor [[Idris Elba]]<ref>{{Citation|title=Yardie (film)|date=2018-06-09|url=https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Yardie_(film)&oldid=845168942|work=Wikipedia|language=en|access-date=2018-06-25}}</ref> made his directorial debut with his feature film [[Yardie (film)|''Yardie'']], based on Headley's book.
== Criminal activity == Yardie gangs are notorious for their involvement in [[gun crime]] and the [[illegal drug trade]], notably [[cannabis (drug)|marijuana]] and [[crack cocaine]] in the [[United Kingdom]]. In 1993, Yardies were blamed for the murder of Police Constable Patrick Dunne, shot dead while patrolling in [[Clapham]].<ref name="Arnold2012">{{cite book|author=Catharine Arnold|title=Underworld London: Crime and Punishment in the Capital City|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qa9gH3hdoYEC&pg=PT407|date=5 July 2012|publisher=Simon and Schuster|isbn=978-0-85720-117-1|pages=407–}}</ref> In 2006, Rohan Chung, described as a Jamaican yard gangster was given three life sentences for the murders of Noel Patterson and his daughters, Connie and Lorna Morrison.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/yardie-convicted-over-triple-murder-7192598.html|title=Yardie convicted over triple murder|last=|first=|date=17 January 2006|work=Evening Standard|access-date=25 June 2018}}</ref>
[[United Kingdom|British]] police are hesitant to categorize Yardie gangs as organized crime, since there appears to be no real structure or central leadership; gang affiliations can be described as loose at best.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/371604.stm|title=Who are the Yardies?|last=|first=|date=19 June 1999|website=BBC News|archive-url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/371604.stm|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=25 June 2018}}</ref> Neither have Yardies made any attempts at setting up fronts for their illegal activities, nor any serious attempts to corrupt and infiltrate law enforcement organisations.{{citation needed|date=November 2014}} Academics have noted a tendency to over-label black British crime as "Yardie"-related due to stereotype and social narrative.<ref name="FijnautPaoli2007">{{cite book|author1=Cyrille Fijnaut|author2=Letizia Paoli|title=Organised Crime in Europe: Concepts, Patterns and Control Policies in the European Union and Beyond|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-XtKAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA428|date=21 January 2007|publisher=Springer Science & Business Media|isbn=978-1-4020-2765-9|pages=428–}}</ref>
A number of operations to combat Yardie gun crime have been set up, notably [[Operation Trident (Metropolitan Police)|Operation Trident]] in the [[London]] area.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/398197.stm "Police tackle London's Yardies"], BBC News, 20 July 1999.</ref> Yardies (or imitating) gangs also appear to be active in [[Bristol]], [[Birmingham]], [[Aberdeen]], [[Edinburgh]] and [[Nottingham]] but to a lesser extent.
Some maintain that the supposed reach and influence in communities of these "Yardies" is a myth.<ref name="bbc"/>
==In popular culture== ===Films and television series=== * ''[[The Harder They Come]]'' (1972) * ''[[Live and Let Die (film)|Live and Let Die]]'' (1973) * ''[[Marked for Death]]'' (1990) * ''[[Predator 2]]'' (1990) * ''[[Rumble in the Bronx]]'' (1995) * ''[[Snatch (film)|Snatch]]'' (2000) *''[[Triads, Yardies and Onion Bhajees]]'' (2003) * ''[[Rollin' with the Nines]]'' (2006) * ''[[Running Scared (2006 film)|Running Scared]]'' (2006) * ''[[Shottas]]'' (2006) * ''[[Ross Kemp on Gangs]]'' (2007) * ''[[The Other Guys]]'' (2010) * ''[[Castle (TV series)|Castle]]'' (2012) * ''[[Luke Cage (TV series)|Luke Cage]]'' (2018) * ''[[Yardie (film)|Yardie]]'' (2018)
===Video games=== * ''[[Grand Theft Auto (video game)|Grand Theft Auto]]'' (1997) * ''[[Grand Theft Auto III]]'' (2001) * ''[[The Getaway (video game)|The Getaway]]'' (2002) * ''[[Gangs of London]]'' (2006) * ''[[Grand Theft Auto IV]]'' (2008)

revision.text:
[[File:Palmerston NZ Boer War Memorial closer.jpg|230px|thumb|right|The Fallen Soldiers’ Memorial in [[Palmerston, New Zealand|Palmerston]] depicting ''Zealandia'' pointing heavenward, was unveiled in 1903.<ref>[https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/ODT19030615.2.82.26?query=zealandia%20rifles Papers Past] | PALMERSTON FALLEN SOLDIERS'MEMORIAL ...</ref>]] '''''Zealandia''''' is a [[national personification]] of [[New Zealand]]. In her stereotypical form, Zealandia appears as a woman of European descent who is similar in dress and appearance to [[Britannia]], who is said to be the mother of Zealandia.<ref name="Glover">[[Denis Glover|Denis James Matthews Glover]], [http://www.teara.govt.nz/en/1966/zealandia/1 "A National Symbol?"] in ''[[An Encyclopaedia of New Zealand]]'' ([[Alexander Hare McLintock|A. H. McLintock]] ed, 1966)</ref>
==History== As a direct link to both [[Motherland|Mother]] [[United Kingdom|Britain]] and the old world, she brought a sense of history and classical respectability to the [[Colony of New Zealand|colony]] during the formative years as a young nation. Zealandia appeared on [[postage stamp]]s, posters, cartoons, war memorials, and New Zealand government publications most commonly during the first half of the 20th century.<ref>[https://www.nzgeo.com/stories/zealandia-mother-of-the-nation/ ZEALANDIA – MOTHER OF THE NATION?] - New Zealand Geographic</ref> Zealandia was a commonly used symbol of the [[New Zealand Centennial Exhibition]], which was held in [[Wellington]] in 1939 and 1940. Three large Zealandia statues exist in New Zealand towns or cities; one is in [[Waimate]], one is in [[Palmerston, New Zealand|Palmerston]], and one in [[Newton, New Zealand#Symonds Street|Symonds Street]], [[Auckland]]. The first two (in stone) are [[Second Boer War]] memorials and the latter one (in bronze) is a [[New Zealand Wars]] memorial. Some smaller statues exist in museums and in private hands.
===Postage stamps===
[[File:1901 Universal Postage 1 penny red.JPG|145px|thumb|right|''Zealandia'' on a [[Postage stamps and postal history of New Zealand#Universal one penny postage|1901 postage stamp.]]]] Zealandia also featured on one penny definitive postage stamps issued in 1901 and 1909 during the reign of [[Queen Victoria]] and [[Edward VII]] when it went from being a Colony to a [[Dominion of New Zealand|Dominion]] and was also depicted on a stamp featuring the coat of arms issued in 1929.
==Coat of arms== The woman who appears on the left side of the [[coat of arms of New Zealand]] is Zealandia.<ref name="Glover"/><ref>[http://www.ngw.nl/int/nzl/nz-nat.htm Heraldry of the World] New Zealand Coat of Arms page</ref> Apart from the coat of arms, Zealandia is seldom depicted in works today, or indeed referred to.<ref>{{cite journal | url=http://www.nzgeographic.co.nz/archives/issue-23/zealandia-mother-of-the-nation | title=Zealandia-mother of the nation? | journal=[[New Zealand Geographic]] |date=July–Sept 1994 | issue=23}}</ref>
==Image gallery== <center> <gallery> File:Coat of arms of New Zealand (1911–1956).svg|''Zealandia'' on the left side of the [[coat of arms of New Zealand]] used from 1911 to 1956. File:Coat of arms of New Zealand.svg|''Zealandia'' on the left side of the [[coat of arms of New Zealand]], used currently. File:Australian ogre 1900.jpg|A political cartoon from 1900 using ''Zealandia'' to represent New Zealand.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.TeAra.govt.nz/en/the-new-zealanders/5/1/1 |author=[[Jock Phillips]] |title=The New Zealanders: Lampooning the Australian federation |work=Te Ara - the [[Encyclopedia of New Zealand]] |date=4 March 2009 |accessdate=11 May 2011}}</ref> File:New Zealand Centennial Exhibition - Certificate of Attendance.jpg|New Zealand Centennial Exhibition. c. 1939 File:Zealandia Symonds Street Auckland.jpg|The New Zealand wars memorial in Auckland File:Zealandia Symonds Street Auckland 5.jpg|The Bronze Zealandia statue in Auckland </gallery> </center>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== {{commons category|Zealandia}} *[https://blogs.otago.ac.nz/thehockenblog/2010/11/22/all-hail-zealandia/ National song: "All Hail! Zealandia!"] composed by Robert Peel Crosbie, published in 1885 with a dedication to former premier Sir [[Julius Vogel]]. *"[http://timespanner.blogspot.com/2009/01/ah-zealandia-what-has-become-of-thee.html Ah, Zealandia -- what has become of thee?]" "Timespanner" (Avondale Historical Society), 28 January 2009. Retrieved 15 December 2010.
